Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		Authoritarian

He took two marbles from the second pot, so there are 5 marbles left in the second pot. Finally, Aaron takes three marbles from the second pots and puts four marbles into the second pot.  He now has 7 marbles back in the bottom pot and is only missing five marbles in the second pot. Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructor:<n>* **The correct response to this question is C.**<n>* It's great that you identified that the choices were opposite, however you still need to recognize which answer corresponds to which question. If Hurley is Richard's age 20 years from now, Richard would have to be 40 now.<n><n>* The question here involves addition and subtraction which both involve numbers. Hurley is 100 away from 140. In addition, Richard is older than Hurley and we also know that Hurley is 18 (older than teenagers).<n><n>* From the question, it seems like all the friends have had 815 days of reading. From there, 815 = 6 * 20 and we subtract 815 - 6 * 2o to get the number of books.<n><n>* The correct answer to this one is A.<n><n>* The car wash only takes out 10% of the money, the group has $100, and they have a total cost of $1700.<n><n>* The teacher appreciation gifts cost $6. The cost of 1 egg would be $0.15*6 to get a cost of $0.90 per egg.<n><n>* There's not enough information to answer this one.<n><n>* Excellent! The friends made $600 by using eBay. And their friend Aurelia made $420 by using eBaay.

Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		 A is closest; D is farthest because bald eagles don’t live in skies, or washington they live in the wildlife refuge, in the open country or in the pine tree (pine trees are found in the open country).<n><n>### Instructor's Feedback:<n>Congratulations! On the porch C.  At the school D.  At the pet store<n><n>  > Your response:<n>  * Choices that are closer together are closer, and choices further away are farther away. This means that A. the porch is closer than B. under the porch.<n><n>  * But then which is the furthest away? Choice D. is the one farthest away: The other choices are all closer to us. So the closest place C. at the school is the best place, and the farthest away A. under the porch is the place the dog should avoid.<n><n>### Task: 2<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Feedback:<n><table border="1" style="background-color: white; width: 80%; border-radius: 5px"><n>    <tr><n>      <th rowspan="2">Choice</th><n>      <th colspan="3" rowspan="6">A: Auntie Jill</th><th colspan="3">B: Dad</th><th colspanc="3">C: Mummy and Daddy</th><n>    </tr>

Choices: A.330 B. a lot C. about 30% D.10<n><n>Input 2 Response: B<n><n>### Demosatration 2<n><n>Input 2 Demosatration: Input 2 is: <span style="color: darkred">b</span><n><n>### Answer 2:<n><n>Answer 2: <span style="background-color: darkred">330</span><n><n>Answer 2 Solution: The 2-for-2 tickets total 135 tickets. We take 135 tickers and divide by 61 rows, to get 2.25 tickets per row. There are 8 rows in the theater, so that means that there are going to be 9 rows of tickets that are free. There are about 83 tickets that are 2-for$1. That means that there are about 83 - 9 (free seats)= 74 non-free seats in the theater.  <n><n><n>### Problem 2<n><n>Pablo is a library manager that takes 15.1 dollars from every book returned. Choices:  A: circus B: carnival C: surprise D: spoons E: party<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the man is planning on running away with an Circus, then he went to Clown college. <n><n>Clown College was established in 1991 and located in Orangeburg, SC. <n><n>It was founded by Dick Barton, a professor of clowning at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, and Debbie Brown.<n><n>Clown college costs about $10,000 but has a scholarship program with about 30% full tuition scholarship for first time students. <n><n>There are many different skills that people learn. This could include juggling, unicycling, balance, and skits.<n><n>### Answer:<n>a.1. I had to pay $20 for my membership to the Sewing Circle.<n>  <n>    I had to pay an additional $2 to make a donation to the Sewing Club's charity fund.<n>    As part of my membership to the Sawing Circle, I needed a membership card.<n>  <n>    The membership card costs $0.50.<n>    There was a special card that had the words "I'm a Member" printed on it and it contained the information about the Sewing Circle on the back. This card cost $5.<n><n>b.3. $1.25<n><n>### Answer (Teacher):<n><n>a. 1. It is a mistake in the first case to use $20 and $2 instead of $0.20 and $0.02.<n>  <n>I paid $1.25 for my membership to the club because in the second case, instead of using $0.50 for the membership card, I used $5 for the special card.<n><n>b. 3. My response is correct because the value obtained in $1.25 is the same as the one obtained in my submission to the Teacher<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>a. 3. My answer is correct since the cost of the membership card is 50 cents and not 20 cents.<n>b. 4. 6.57 <n>

Choices:  A: illiterate B: knowledgable C: own house D: have enough food E: meet expectations<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input 2: What is the solution to 41 – (55 ÷ 2) > 2?<n><n>### Response 2: 42<n><n>## Solution<n><n>[1](https://i.imgur.com/bUHrUVX.jpg) In this solution, the main idea is to create an array of objects and call a method in both of them. The main task is the difference in ages and it is called the **answer**.<n>```javascript<n>function sumOfAge(first, second){<n>	return first.getAge() + second.getAge();<n>}<n><n>function getAge(person) {<n>	return new Date().getFullYear() - (person.getFullYear() - person.getAge());<n>}<n><n>function Person(name, age) {<n>	this.name = name;<n>	this.age = age;<n><n>	this.getAge = function(){<n>		return getAge(this);<n>	}<n>}<n><n>const richard = new Person("Richard", 25);       <n>const hurley = new Person("Hurley", 14);<n><n>const sum = sumOfAge(richard, hurley );<n><n>console.log(sum);<n>```<n>[Reference](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8rWmYEpGD3Y)<n><n>#### Reference<n>[YouTube Video](https://www.udemy.com/course/javascript/lecture/20706352)<n><n>##### Acknowledgements<n><n>- [Aaron](https://github.com/aaron016a)<n>- Youtube: Teodor<n><n><n>[1](

What are conditions to ensure that each patient leaves in a different cab?**<n><n>```<n>> Every one had at least two patients each at one time<n>> The patient who wanted to leave first had to pick up the last patient to leave, the patient who had picked the patient who had the next to the last patient, and the third patient to leave who picked the second last to leave patient<n>> The patients had to leave in the reverse order of their arrival to the ward after their room assignment by the nurse<n>> And no two patient leaves in a different taxicab

A customer wants to buy 6 gallons of orange juice and 7 gallons of grapefruit juices. Her total shopping bill must be exactly $18.00. How many gallons of apple juice and orange juice must she purchase in order to fulfill this bill?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>You start with 6x2 = 12 - you need to get one more<n>7x4 = 28 then you need the rest - (6 + 28) = 34 then 34x2 = 68<n><n>### Instraction:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>First you subtract because they have 19 12 -17 <n>Then you multiply and divide  14 14/2<n>That is 7 then you subtract 7x4 = 30 <n>Then 13- 30 = 0 +13  <n><n><n>## Instrucion:The price of a small and large ice cream cone at the ice cream parlor is $1.75. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		I think it may be choice "E": it would be a high school band that sounds unpleasant to listeners because it is high school band playing. Another possible answer is choice "D". A symphony would be unpleasing to listeners if it was made by someone who doesn't know the proper way to make symphonies. Finally, a baritone woodwind sounds unpleasing when it's bad, but also when the baritone woodwind is played a little. It all really depends on the person playing it and how they sound. For example, if one person played the baritone wood on key, it'd sound more pleasant.  Choices "B" and "C" were probably not chosen because they could be answered by students who don't think music sounds pleasant when it's not made by professionals or when it's not played on a good instrument.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>How much money would you get to keep after purchasing tickets to see a musical, spending $600 for the tickets and spending $80 for dinner?<n><n>### Response<n>If we are going to use the musical ticket expense in the calculations, I would expect to only spend $880.25 ($600 + $22.77 for tax and $80 +$1.26 for tip). According to the question as stated, we should receive $157.75.<n>If the $600 are for the actual cost of the tickets only (and not the costs of tax and tip), I would expect to only receive $918.25 ($626+$192).<n>

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where do kids find fish in their backyards? Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		If the question does not ask a multiple choice question, the student should provide a sentence response to a question in their own words.<n><n><n>### Input<n>### <n>The teacher asked, "How many days have there been between springing forward and falling back?<n><n>### <n>I think there are about 78, maybe 79 or 80.<n><n>###  A) If the question is asking the student to identify a date and count days before or after it, the student should write the response in the form of a sentence and provide the number of the date and the number of days if there are additional questions.<n>### <n>### <n>If there are less than 15 problems a student writes the answer, when there are 15 or more the student writes "I am not sure of an amount."

If hurley is 14 year's old what are their ages 30 day's from now<n>  what are their combined ages?<n><n>### Solution:<n>   <n>    Sum = A+B<n>    A = 22<n>    B = Sum - A<n>    Sum = A<n>    <n>  Let x = A<n>  A = 22 - x<n>    x = Sum + A<n>    Sum += A<n>    x = sum - A<n>    Sum + A = <n>    Sum = x<n>    A+B = 22 + 14<n>    A  = 22 - 14 + 7<n>    A  = Sum<n>    A  = Age<n>    <n>    <n>    Sum = Age - 22<n><n><n><n><n>### Question<n><n>       A group of seven friends got together and decided to share a cab trip. If the fare was $15.00, how much did each person pay?<n>  <n>  <n>  <n><n>  <n>  <n>### Solution:  <n><n>    Add = 15.00<n><n>    A =7<n><n>    A = 15<n><n>    A = A + 0<n><n>### Question  <n>    <n>       How much is 15% of 3661.<n>    <n><n>##  ##Question<n>  Find the difference between the greatest common factor of the pair of numbers 26 and 210.<n><n>##  ## Solution<n><n>### First step<n><n>  What is the greatest common factor:  26 <n><n>  Now divide:         210 <n><n>### Second step<n><n>  The remainder:         6<n><n>  The remainder after:     26<n><n>### Solution  <n><n>       26 is 6 greater than the greatest common factor of 26 and 30<n><n>## Question<n><n>Let us say the current temperature is 29 degrees Fahrenheit. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a landlocked, southern state, where is this person? Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def dictionary_play(chall):<n><n>#challenge<n>if (chall == 'A'):<n>    chalg = 'A'<n><n>elif (chall == 'B'):<n>    chalg= 'B'<n><n>elif (<n>    chall == 'C'):<n>    chalg='D'<n><n>elif ( chall == 'D'):<n>    chalg  ='E'<n><n>elif (  chall =='E'):<n>    chalg=='None'<n><n>print (chalg)<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>The first day of third grade, the teacher explains a new strategy to help the class learn the material. <n><n>For example, for each concept,  the teacher will call on a child to define what the concept is. <n><n>After the first concept is explained, the teacher will give the rest of the class one opportunity to explain the second concept. <n><n>After all the students have had one attempt to define the second concept, the teacher will call on another student for their second shot. <n><n>The teacher will keep calling on every student in class one by one until everyone in the class has been able to explain the second concept twice. <n><n>This will then be followed by the third concept and so on.<n><n>How much work will each student in the class do if we assume that the teacher will give one student the chance to explain each concept?<n><n>Output:<n>Assuming you know that each day of the school year will have 180 school days, calculate the total number of work the students will do each school year.<n><n>### Input and Output:<n><n><n>				Sarah has 293 items in her inventory. 29% of her inventory are clothing items. 41 items in her inventory are books. 50 items in her inventory consist of accessories. Choices:  A: study philosophy B: become adult C: ask questions D: further education E: study together<n><n>### Response:		The students are trying to study philosophy<n><n>#### Explanation:In this response the student has chosen the correct answer:<n><n>---<n><n>:construction: Input:Their dog sleeps in a dog house every night. Their cat sleeps in a box in the bedroom every night. After sleeping in the dog house for 6 days, the cat still sleeps in the box in the bedroom that same night. How many days will they sleep in the box in the room?<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>> We can replace the word ‘dog’ with ‘my’ and ‘cat’ with ‘mom’.<n><n><n>> My dog sleeps in a house every night<n><n>> My cat sleeps in a house in the bedroom everynight<n><n>Therefore, my cat sleeps in a doghouse every night.<n><n><n>---<n>### Explanaton:<n>>We know that the time spent in a room equals to the time spent sleeping.<n><n><n><br/><br/><n><n>---<n><n>### Inputs:  A: 3 B: 2<n><n>### Exlanations:<n><n>> If the person is 2, the total amount of time spent in a room is 3, because 2 + 3 = 5. And our guess is 3.<n><n><br/><n><n>> If the guess is 5 the amount of time the person has spent in a room is not enough (Because 5 > 3).<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n>    The answer is <n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><h3>What is the combined cost of the books?</h3><n><p>One cent per page = Total cost = 150 pages/10 cents = 25 pages</p><n><p>Total cost = $3.75</p><n><h3>Did Pablo read 4 books?</h3><p>50 cents per page = Total cost - $15 = $27.75<n><n>50 cents per 150 pages, subtract $15 gives 27.75, divide by 2 equals 13.88<n><n>13.88 / 15 => 27.742857143 = 28 pages</p><n><n><h3> Did each driver pay $140?</h3> <p> $140 is $2 per page.<n><n>Total number of pages divided per each friend<n><n>238 pages / 6 friends = 39.66 pages per person.</p><n><h2> What is the remaining cost?</h2><n><p> Total remaining cost: $1186 </p><n><p > Each person's cost: 1186 / 6 = $197 </p> <p> Each person's cost subtracted from cost left = $1186 - $197 = $989</p><n><div> $989 / 6 = $340 </div><h3>How much did each gift cost if the chef made 3 cakes?</h3>	<div>  $344 = $1410 - $1060 </div><n><div>  $1410 / 6 = $235 </div><n>

The sentence "after getting his report card, billy was worried that his..." tells us that he is in this situation now, then the next part says "his parents agreed to buy him" which is past and that wasn't included in this problem but it shows that Billy is worried and his parents aren't mad.<n><n>### Note:<n>Make sure you answer the questions as described in the instruction.<n>

Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		It happens to people<n><n>```<n>Congratulations, your solution to the "Instruction" was accepted!<n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```js<n>function solve1(){<n>  var answer = Math.floor(parseInt(Math.random() * 6));<n><n>  while (answer === 0){<n>    for (var i = 1; i < 6; i++) {<n>      var newAnswer = Math.floor(Math.random()*6);<n>      if (newAnswer!== answer){<n>        answer = newAnswer;<n>        break;<n>      }<n>    }<n>  }<n>  return answer<n>}<n><n>function solve2(){<n>  var input1 = prompt("answer the following multiple choice question");<n>  var answer1 = Math.floor(solve1())<n><n>  var input2 = prompt("Demonstration:");<n>  var answer2 = Math.floor(input2.split(":")[1])<n><n>  var response1 = Math.floor((1.1+parseFloat(input1))/solve1());<n>  var response2 = Math.floor(((1.1+parsefloat(input2.split("<--")[1]))/solve2()));<n><n>  console.log(response1, response2);<n>}<n><n>solve2();<n>```<n><n>```<n>Celebration!<n><n>Congratulations! You’ve completed a sample tutorial. You can find many more tutorials through the Codespace link in the sidebar. To browse all courses and tutorials, visit [Tutorials](http://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/tutorials).<n>```

Write a response that describes the solution in your own words.<n><n>## Demo:<n><n>Solution: In order to find the number of words, you should count the number of words after the first number.<n><n>If you know the first word, 199, then you’ll know the whole word after this number. There are 3 spaces and the second word is 98. Counting these spaces, it can be discovered that there are 4 spaces in the word and the whole word can be interpreted as 199.98. If it was a different word, then it is the second number, 772.23. By finding the first number, it’s possible to find that the second word is, then it’s the 3rd number, which is the number after that and so on until you get the next word.<n><n>## Instruction :<n><n>Below is a multiple choice question. Answer the following open-ended question.<n><n>## Input:What do humans<n><n>### Response  : Humans, like most other animals, have offspring. Offspring is what they call their babies. It can be a child, a cat, a snake, or a plant. Babies can even be an idea! Humans can produce babies. Humans use the method called "sex". The opposite of sex is called masturbation. The end result of sex is babies. The babies from sex are called progeny.

However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Test Data<n><n>```<n>(3) <n><n>(1) <n><n>(5) <n><n>(2) <n><n>(4) <n><n>(0) <n><n>(31)<n><n>```<n><n>### Expected Response<n><n>```<n>A<n>```<n><n>## Test #2:<n>(Below is an instruction that describes an algorithm). Write a complete program that uses logical symbols to show a sequence of instructions that appropriately completes this task.<n><n>### Requirements:<n>1. Readers can only add new symbols if the user is not currently in a comment.<n>2. The user should not be able to add symbols if they are currently in a comment. <n>3. After a symbol has been added, a corresponding comment should automatically be created that has the name of the symbol and its corresponding number.<n>4. The number next to the symbol should be the number in which comments are being made as the comments are added. <n>5. A user should be able to comment on their own previous comment.<n>6. Comments are only allowed to be one level deep.<n>6. A user should be allowed to delete previous comments and their corresponding number.<n>7. The program should prompt the user when a comment number is higher than the highest comment number the user has created. They should warn the user that they are above the limit and then ask them to enter another number.<n>8. Every user can only have a maximum of up to 1,000 comments on their board.<n>9. Every comment the user makes should have one of the following symbols:<n><n><pre><n><n>* &lt; &gt;?<n><n></pre><n><n>### Instructions:<n>You are to write a program that allows all the following statements to be added in real time.<n><n>1. A user can enter a name and add it as a symbol.<n>2. A user can enter their comment on the symbol and then number it with a number (for example 1).<n>3. A user can delete a previous comment by erasing the entire symbol (for example: 1) they deleted and can replace it with another symbol again.<n>4. A user can comment on their previous comment.<n>5. A user can add another comment after their previous comment.<n>6.A user can exit the prompt by typing the number of their last comment

What was the total cost the new owner had with new tires?<n><n>### Input<n>It is hard to know how many tires would be on the car but as the owner had 4 tires it says the cost of the new tires is $88. <n><n>We know that the cost of the new car was $88 if there are 4 tiers on the car. Since the price of the new tiers is increasing by 8% this would increase the cost of the car 8% by which could be calculated as 0.08x88 = $7.28. <n><n>### Responses<n>This means that if there are 4 new tiers on the car then the price of the entire car increases by 0.08 x 88 which is $7.28 and the cost of the new tier increases from $22 to $23.71.<n><n>### Input How many pencils did Benny have at the stationary shop if he is going to use 22 pencils for every 5 different people on a project. Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the "Response" section below, copy and paste your code into one of the options provided.<n>Select your answer, and then press the "check answer" button.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input<n><n>|  |  |  | <n>| :----: | :----: | :--------: | <n>| Choice | Answer |<n>| Option A | 1500 | 666 | <n>| Option B | 12 | 8640 | <n>| Option C | 6 | 1278 | <n>| Option D | 16 | 28 | <n>|Option E|36  |54 |<n><n>**Option A**<n>```<n>from operator import getitem<n><n>x = 15<n><n>n = 1000<n><n>sum = 0<n><n>for counter in range(n):<n>  sum = sum + x<n><n>print(sum)<n>```<n><n>**Option B**<n><n>```<n>from operator<n>from math import floor<n><n><n>def calculate_number(choice):<n>	if choice=="1":<n>		n=20<n>		sum=20<n>	elif choice=="2":<n>		n=-2<n>		sum=-2<n>	return sum<n><n><n>print(calculate_number(choice))<n>```<n><n>**option C**<n>```<n>x = (3 * 2000)/4 + (10 * 14)/6+ 3<n>print(x)<n><n>```<n><n>**Options D**<n>```<n>x=6  <n><n><n>y=3<n><n>z=15<n><n>g=30<n><n>if y==g:<n><n>	print(y)<n>else:<n><n>	print('z')<n>```<n><n>**options E**<n>```<n>x=(10-15)x10<n>y=x-10<n><n>z=y+1<n><n>print (z)<n>```<n>

You land at another city, where the time is 9:00. Which of the following are true about this?<n><n>I. The sun is rising.<n><n>II. It is 11:00PM at the first city.<n><n>III. The sun is setting.<n><n>IV. It is 10:00PM at both cities.<n><n>Answer: III<n><n>### Input You are looking at the picture for clue<n><n>### Demand:What is the area of the picture you are looking at? <n><n>### Response Area = 591<n><n>### Input What can you see in the picture?  Listed in order<n><n>### Request Write 4 clues, listed in order <n><n>### Demainstration 1:<n>Input: The area of the picture you can see is 34 sq in.<n>Answer: You’ll need a 1 inch ruler to measure all the squares. <n><n>Input: The area is 4,000 sq ft.<n>Answer:  You’ll need a ruler to measure all those squares.<n><n>Input: The squares have a perimeter of 48.<n>Answer:  There’s only 24 squares in the picture you are looking. <n><n>Input The perimeter of each square is 6.<n>Answer: The area can be written like this 121 <n><n>### Feedback<n>###### Write a new task here<n><n>###### __________ (your name) <n><n>###### When it’s written, it’s _____. <n><n>###### Write a response for the request<n><n>__________, <n><n>###### _____. <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What city in the middle east is known for a temple? Choices:  A: jerusalem B: texas C: middle east D: china E: india<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input Choice:<n>A,C,D<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer should have correct amount of characters.<n><n><n>### Input<n>What is the capital city of the United Kingdom? (Choose from List: London,Birmingham, Cardiff,Manchester,Edinburgh,Nottingham)  <n><n>### Response with choices<n><n><n>## Solver Code (100% Correct)<n><n>```python<n><n>    def main():<n>        a = 'london'<n>        print ('London is the capital city of The United Kingdom.')<n><n>   <n><n><n>```<n><n>## Input:<n><n>What is the capital of America? (Choose from: Washington DC, Boston, New York, Phoenix)<n><n>## Response:<n><n><n>## Solve Code (100%)<n><n>```python<n>def guess(question, guess):<n>    if guess == question:<n>        print('you are Correct')<n>    elif question!= guess:<n>        print('wrong')<n>        guess(question, guess)<n>```<n><n>```python<n>question = "What is the capital of america"<n><n>guess(question,'Washington DC')<n>```<n><n>### Output<n><n><n>you are Correct<n><n>## A problem with some missing characters in the answer.<n><n>    def main():<n>        answer: 'wrong'<n><n>        <n>### Change <n><n>### Output:<n><n>```python<n>wrong<n><n>```<n><n><n>## Input: A group of sixteen friends planned to buy a new car. Their total salary is $80,000. They are going to pay the rest at $500 per week. They each started $500 in the first week. If they saved correctly and still had the same amount $80,016 after four years, how much money does each person have in their savings?<n><n>### Response/Code:<n><n> <n>```python<n>if x < y:`python<n><n>if x - y > 500:<n>    x = x + 500<n>else:<n>    y = y - 500<n><n>for x in [10000, 15000, 25000,1000]:<n><n>    y = y + int(

The helm is the instrument used to move the masts on a ship.<n>>A B: <n>>1 C: <n>>1 D: <n>>1 E: <n>>1<n><n>### Response<n>A helm is not something worn on your head, but rather a ship instrument that moves the mast.<n><n>### Response 128<n>The solution is $40, because the sum of $12 and $14 is $26, and $26 - $12 is $14.

For example, variable ‘x’ might represent $200 or a sentence.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>$x varies from $100 to $500<n><n>I want to go to the store and buy variable ‘x’ dollars worth of groceries<n><n>In this case $x varies from $5 to $25 (or any money on between that in this case)<n><n>Variable “d” might represent degrees Fahrenheit or centimeters<n><n>There are other examples so in all cases you will need to do your research for your lesson<n><n>### Assignment:<n>-  Include 10-15 examples<n>-  In text format (example: If ‘x’ varies from $200 to $576 and ‘y’ varies from 1-5 feet, then ‘x’ is equal to ‘y’ + 5, then ‘x’ will be...

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she wanted to get good grades? Choices:  A: feel proud B: try to learn C: need assistance D: thank god E: read alot<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E or A, since they are both options of B. Read A LOT can be a form of reading alot I guess. B and C both need some form of help.<n><n>### Input - D:  There were 21 guests at the party.  There were 3 more women than children.  If there were 16 children, how many children were present at the party?<n><n>### Response - E:  16 (6+6, with two left over)

He wants to make a table where he tracks the number of times people with each blood group were born in every generation. If a person’s blood type is determined by their genetic parentage and passed down from generation to generation, which blood type should have been born the most and which blood type should have decreased the most?<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is “The blood type with the highest frequency will have the greatest increase in each<n>generation and the blood type with the lowest will decrease in each generation.”<n><n>### InputThe class is preparing a food drive to support their local food pantry. The word ungulate means ‘plant-eating mammal with certain anatomical features,’ so the choice makes sense.<n><n>Input:Mallory went to the gym five times this week and weighed each time she went. She also weighed herself each of the five days she went to the gym. Mallory could tell that she had lost weight over the week. How much weight did Mallory lose this week at the gym? Please explain your steps.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>$>$ (24,76,18,63,52) # weight<n>54 # number of days<n>0.2 $<n> 96 # the weights of the 5 days<n>  84 + 96 = 180 g = 177 g # total weight lost over the week<n>```<n>### Instruction<n>Answer the five questions that follow this instruction.<n><n>### Input<n>You have heard that children are like sponges, absorbing information and lessons like a sponge absorbs water. What you may not know is it is not only the knowledge that sticks. It may very well be the emotions associated with a lesson that sticks better than the actual content of the lesson. When your child was 3 years old and first learned about her 4 o’clock rule it was more the associated emotion that had a huge impact rather than the actual lesson. The emotion was so strong at age 3 that 10 years later it is still an emotion she clings to in her heart and mind and is a great motivational tool for her now teenage self. What emotional lesson will your child cling to forever knowing, now as an adult, how important it was to her when she learned it?<n><n>### Response 1<n>"I can use my words and express what I think."<n><n>"I know I always get my way."<n><n>"I can help!"<n><n>### Response #2<n>"I can do it!"<n><n>"I know my worth and I put value in myself."<n><n>"I deserve to succeed."<n><n>### Response :<n>It’s fun to learn!<n><n>It’s important to be curious and ask questions.<n><n>I learn better when there’s interaction and movement.<n><n>### Expected Response<n>You

Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>(Answer: C)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: The pizza company has 64 pepperoni and 36 cheese pizza available. The manager gives out one pizza at a time. If the company takes in half the pizzas as they give out, the manager knows they will have 60 pepperoni and 10 cheese left. How many of each pizza does the manager give out?<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>## A cheese pizza will leave the company with 10, but half of pizzas is only 12 pizzas, not 13.<n><n>## Input 1: The pizza company gives out one pizza a time.<n><n>## Input2: The company takes in only half the number of pizzas as they gave out.<n><n>## Input3: The manager knows they will have left with 60 pepperone, 10 cheese pizzas.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>## After taking out 1 pizza, the company will have 16 pizzas to give out as pepperoni.<n><n>## That leaves 48 pizzas to give to cheese.<n><n>## They will then have 48 cheese pizzas left over, leaving 2 pepperoni cheese pizzas for the manager to choose from.<n><n>## Input4: The manager will choose 1 pepperoni chees pizza leaving the company with 2 pizzas.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where can I find a steakhouse with a view of corn fields? Choices:  A: nebraska B: new york C: mexico D: home E: utah<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Answer:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><img src="https://github.com/w3designer2005/AlgorithmsProject/blob/master/Week%201/Demonstration.gif"><n><n>### Testing<n><n><b>Test:</b><n><n><img src="http://flipflapflap.com/gameplay/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/3.gif" width="300px"><n><img src=" http://i1.wp.com/techcrunch.com/wp-content/gallery/mobile-world-congress/MWC2013-Sony-Xperia-Z1-17.jpg?w=588&ssl=1" width="400px"><n><n>Result: Aurelia<n><n>### Next Question<n><img src=""><n><img src="/images/week%201%20next.png" width="200px"/><n><img src="/Images/week%204.png" width="450px"><n><div align="right"><n>	<img src="https: //media.giphy.com/media/xTqVnwSBXJqIaD2QmF/giphy.gif" width="40%"/><n>	</div><!--<n><n>		https://twitter.com/<n>	--><n><n>### References<n><img src="/pdf/week%203%20Demonstration.pdf" width="600px"/><n><n><img src="/img/week1.png"/><n><n><n>### Assignments<n>* [Week 2](https://github.com//w3designer271/AlgorithmsProject/tree/master/Week2)<n>* [Week 3](https://github.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Demositration:<n><n>### Input

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option (A): drink tea<n><n>### Input (Cont.).:A young chef decided to bake a cake to celebrate her dad’s birthday. Her mum suggested the idea, and the young chef was unsure about what ingredient to select, so she chose a random option (A, B, C, D, or E) for the ingredient. How happy was the young chef? <n><n>A: a cup of flour B: a bag of icing sugar C: a jar of margarine D: one bunch of almond E: a pack of eggs <n><n>### Answer:<n>Option (B): a jar of margarines<n><n>### Input and Options (Cont.):She had baked this kind of cake, so decided to use the same recipe, and was able to successfully celebrate her dad's birthday. The young chef got an A for the cake and felt very happy after receiving the feedback from her dad. <n><n>What did the chef’s dad find out about her daughter’s cake? <n><n>A:(A,B,C or D) <n><n>### Response Options:(A) B, (B) C, (C) D<n><n>### Rationale:Option (A): Drinks a cup of water (B): Drinks a bottle of milk (C): Drinks a pack of eggs (D): Drinks a pack or margarine (E) Drinks flour<n><n>### Input Cont.(Cont.): The chef’s daughter asked her 4 friends to taste her cake. 2 of her friends said it was amazing and tasty. 2 others were not sure what made her cake so yummy.  Her dad also thought that the cake tasted great and also told the chef that she deserved to have an A. Her mum disagreed with him saying that it was a bit too salty.<n><n>What grade did the chef’s mum give her daughter’s cakes? <n><n>### Inputs:(A) Not satisfied (B) Satisfied (C) Not very impressed (D) Excellent (E) Disappointed<n>### Answer(A): Excellent<n><n>### Input.The chef’s mum was busy all day when her daughter brought the c
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		The people were playing  video game,  because   the lead pencil  has  an eraser.<n><n>### Explanation:The people were playing a video game, because the lead pencil has an eraser.<n>### Explanatory notes:<n><n><n><n>### Difficulty<n><n>Hard<n><n>### Existence<n><n>This skill is present and is fully-active in this context.<n><n>### Authority, Accessibility<n><n>* This skill has been given as an authority authority; it is accessible.<n><n>### Relation<n><n>* This skill is related to:<n>  * [Question Authoring](question-authoring.html)<n><n>### Notes<n><n>* This skill may be used to represent either question types or authoring instructions.<n><n>---<n>© 2020 Trilogy Education Services  All Rights Reserved.<n><n>

Choices:  A: squid B: pencil C: newspaper D: fountain pen E: printer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- if choice is A or B, say “That’s not correct.”<n>- otherwise, say “You are correct!”<n><n>### Input<n><n>The number of apples in the basket is nine greater than the number of apples in her purse. The number in her purse is 23. How many apples are in the basket?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 26<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Fill in the blank: The number of apples in ________ ________ ________, the number in her purse, is 23. If the number of apples is 26, how many apples are in her purse? _________________.<n><n>> Hint: Think about the apples as being like a bank account (her purse)<n>

Choices:  A: refrigerator B: closet C: can D: shelf E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>***A***<n><n>### Instructions:Another question that demonstrates multiple choice skills:<n><n>### Instractions:Write a response to the multiple choice question.<n>### Output:A, B, or C<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### 1. Which of these are real numbers? 1, 53.588, 4, √2, π, 3.141, √7, 3<n><n>### 2. Is 49.999 a real number?<n><n>### 3. How many minutes are there in 8 hours?<n><n>### Instuction: Write a response to this multiple choice problem.<n><n>### Input Demonstration: The input must be a single line, containing the names of up to three numbers 4n, 19m and 7s. Where n, m and s are whole numbers between 0 and 3.<n><n>### Response Demonstration: There can be multiple ways to create a valid response. However, here is one solution: `4n` must be a number between 0 and 9 inclusive. For each n, there is only one 4n possibility. So for n=1, the 4n possibility (because 1<4n) is 4, so 4n=4, but there is no 4n possibility for n=0. It must have a value (but not a negative one). Therefore the 4n for 1, 2 or 3 is one of 4, 16 or 25. The 19m must also be between 0 and 19 inclusive, but 0<19, so 19m doesn't work. Therefore m must be a number between -2 and 17 inclusive. The following combinations of m result in 19m (m<19) and there only being positive 19m combinations. -2 1 11 17. 4n is a number between 0 (excluding it as that's impossible) and 4, so any combination where n<5. 4n=4 if n=0 and n<4, but none of those are valid values for n. If n=1 the valid 4n combinations are

The scammer continues,"In a moment, I will verify your number. If it is the same as what I'm expecting, I will email you a confirmation notification." Then, he hangs up.<n><n>### Response<n>Do not give out any information. The IRS will not contact you by email.<n><n>### Input:"Would you like a car loan or a personal loan?” (or some variation). <n><n>### Response"I would like a car loan."<n><n>### Input"There's a problem with your bank account" <n><n>### Respons<n>Do not click on any links or confirm anything. Call your bank at the phone number on your statement and ask to speak to someone privately.<n><n>### Other tips that may be helpful:<n><n>Don’t use public WiFi networks, cellular data networks, or free WiFi. The connection on one of those unsecured options could be intercepted and hackers could see the passwords you type.  <n>Avoid using public computers—whether at your doctor’s office or a library. Many public machines have a keylogger installed: software that records and sends your keystrokes to a third party.<n><n>### Scam:<n><n>### Scammer:<n><n>### Target:<n><n>

Then the program prints out which numbers will be even if they are evenly divisible by two and which ones will be odd if they are evenly divisible by two.<n><n>### Example Code:<n>```<n>for (i = 1; i < 11; i++) {<n>    if (i % 2 == 0) {<n>        print(i,": even");<n>    } else  {<n>        print(I,": odd");<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>### Your Task:<n><n>### Write a program that prints out which numbers will not be divisible by 2, and which numbers will be!<n><n>### Sample Input:<n>```<n>3<n>5<n>4<n>7<n>```<n><n>### Sample Output:<n>```<n>3  "Divisible by 2"<n>4 "Not divisible by 2" <n>5 "Divisible by two"<n>7 "Not divisible by two"<n>```<n><n>## Coding Questions:<n>1. Can you name an element that uses recursion in everyday life? Explain.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>I can think of two ways a user can use recursion in everyday life to use computers.<n><n>1) When you enter the command prompt and type a program, the computer will have to recurse through all the steps the user tells it to do.<n><n>2) If you had to figure out how to multiply two numbers together, there are two ways of thinking about this problem. A long way of thinking about it and a shorter, easier way to think about it. You could multiply the first number by one, multiply that number by two, and do that for multiple times the number until you get your answer. That is multiplication!<n><n>### 2. In order to figure out if he was at the end of the word, he decided to find the sum of each letter. The number of “a”s and “t”s in the word were 9 and 7, respectively. He multiplied each letter by the total number of “a” and “t”s to get the sum of the word. What was the sum of the word?<n>```<n>### Solution: There are 9 "a"'s and 7 "t"s in the word and the sum of the word is 57(9+7) <n>### Instrucciones: Contestesta el siguiente cuestionario múltiple concreto.<n> <n>### Respuesta:The letter that 'd' is 2 letters away and to the right is 'c'<n> <n>### Instructione: Solve the following question. <n> <n>### Demostraciòn:<n>I had 6 dollars in my wallet and I lost $4. The amount of money that was left unspent must represent the amount that was taken from the total sum.<n><n>### Input 2 : There were 845 people staying at an inn. What percent of the people stayed only four days?<n><n>### Solution 2<n><n>A:<n><n>- [80% x 80% = 64%](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=80%25%20+%2880%25+x+80%25)<n><n>- [15% of 80%(4 days) = 12%](https://www.)<n><n>B:<n><n>- [20% x 8 days = 16%](https://www."<n><n>- [8% of 80 = 6.4%](https://".<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where can you see a mammoth in NYC? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C<n>The rosebush is a common plant in the hedgerow, where it is grown for both its fragrant flowers and its medicinal properties. The term “hedgerow” historically referred to a line of low trees dividing fields and fences, but it is used today to describe the wild areas in the hedgerows which can be planted to grow flowers. These areas can be found along many types of hedges, and grow in moderate climates. The rosebush is considered one of the more popular plants grown in a hedgerow (other hedgerow plants includes holly, ivy, cotoneaster, buckthorn, dogwood, and blackberry. The rosebush gets its name from the pink flowers.<n><n>### Input 2: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input: If Richard is 2 years old, then what is his mother’s current age? Richard is 3 times as old as his  sister Julia who is 10 years old.<n>Answer: 28<n><n>### Response<n><n>**Answer:**<n><n>Julia is 2 years old and Richard is 3 years old<n><n>**Richard’s mother’s current age = 25**<n><n>Richard’s mother is 25, his sister Julia is 10. The problem reads: “Richard is 3 times as his  sister Julia”<n>Than that is Richard is 25 years old and Julia is 10 years which makes 35 years.<n>Than Richard is 1 year older than Julia and Mother is 2 years older than Julia than that is Mother is 36 years old.<n><n>### Credit:<n><n>[J.M]

Therefore, the answer is (A) You go to the basement of the church.<n><n>### Input<n>How much does 1/4 cup of oil weigh? Choices: A: 1 ounce B: 8 ounces C: 16 ounces D: 20 ounces<n><n>### Response<n>If one chooses (B), then the answer to the question “how much does 1/3 cup of oil weigh?” is (D) 8 oz. Therefore, if one can choose (B) then they can choose (C). Thus, the answer is (B) 8 oz<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A man needs to mow his yard. He needs 1/4 acre of grass to be mowed. If he uses 4 gallons of gas to mow 1/4 a cup of grass, how much gas does he need to mow 16 gallons of grass?<n><n>Choice 1:  A: 0.3 gallons of gas B: 160 gallons of gas C: 6 gallons of gas<n>Choice 2:D: 5.93 gallons of gas<n><n>### Response <n>A: It is not possible to answer correctly both ways<n>If the gas used in 1/4 a crop is 4 gallons, then it follows that 1/16 a crop uses (4/4) = 1 gallon of gas. Thus, if one chooses 4 gallons for 1/4 a acre, it follows that 16 acres uses 16X1 = 16 gallons. The answer is thus B. The gas is 160 gallon<n><n>### Input and Response<n>A man fills 4 bottles with 5 gallons each. How much water does he have left? Choices: A; 5 gallons B; 2 gallons C; 300 gallons<n>A man fills 2 containers with the same amount of 8 gallons each. How many 8-gallon containers does it take to fill a 55-gallon container? Choices:  A: chicago B: street C: little italy D: food court E: capital cities<n><n>### Response:		A| The choices are: A and C<n><n>### Instructions:Inspired by the example, write a method to determine an English phrase from an English character string. Remember to return your result from the method, so the code in main can use it.<n><n>### Method:<n>#### Parameter:A String, English character string.<n>#### Return:English phrase.<n><n>### Solution:<n>#### Method Body:<n>##### Input: A String, English character string:<n>>>> example = "apple pie"<n>##### Return:English phrase:<n>>>> print("The example phrase is:", example)<n>The example phrase is: apple pie<n><n>#### Solution Body:<n>```<n>def phrase:<n>    # Method Body<n>    # Parameters<n>        # Param 1: A String, English phrase string<n>    # Return<n>        # Return 1: English phrase<n>    # Implemetation<n>        # In statement<n>            # Create a list as temporary storage<n>            list = example.split(" ")<n>            # If statement1:<n>            if len(list) == 1:<n>                return "".join(list)<n>            # If statement2:<n>            else:<n>                # For loop: For each word in the sentence<n>                    # Input statement<n>                        # Print the current word being processed<n>                        print(word)<n>                    # Return statement<n>                        # Return a phrase that includes the current word<n>                    return "".join(word)<n>    # Return statement:<n>        # Return 2: English phrase<n>    return "".join("".join(word))<n><n>```<n><n>After importing and defining all the classes and methods, implement the methods provided in the table. Write tests using Python unittest. Remember to use the testing methods test.assertIsNone and test.assertEqual as you write your tests.<n><n>### Class:<n>```<n>class Employee:<n>    def __init__(self, name):<n>        self.name = name<n>        self.addresses = []<n><n>### Methods:<n>    def addAddress(self, address):<n>        self.address = address<n>        self.addressed.append("A".join(self.address))<n><n>    def getNameAndAddress(self):<n>        return f"Name: {self.name}, Addresses: {self.address}" <n>```<n>

Choices:  A: write an essay B: organize thoughts C: speak information D: summarize main points E: have information<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: <n><n>#### Summarized solution:Write a response that appropriately does one or more of the following:<n>- Describes what the question is asking for<n><n>- Explains how the question is best approached<n>-- Explains what the correct answer is<n><n>- Explaines how to reach the answer<n>-- Outlines the steps to take<n><n>### Input2<n>How much would it cost to replace 50% of the tires on a car?<n><n>### Response2<n>Answer: <n>I have come up with different ways in my head that I could share it with people, but I want to know what is the most logical and easiest way to share that information with them.<n><n>Social media (tumblr, Instagram, Snapchat, Twitter, etc.)<n><n>Write a short essay or paragraph<n><n>Speak information to people<n><n>Summary main points. <n><n>Social Media is a good way of sharing information, but my parents don't use it and neither do my aunts. It is hard to catch their undivided attention when sharing things, and I can't force them to look at my post or comment, which is why summary and speak out information are better for my audience because it is more likely that they'll hear what I say and make an opinion or change in the way they think (with information). <n><n>So I am going to summarize my answers, and answer my last question on how I will explain something to them the best way there is. <n><n>Summary of how I explained the problems/questions to my friends and why my way of answering is better<n><n>My way of sharing information was better because of who my audience is. <n><n>If I had my aunts or parents, they probably wouldn't have gotten a hold of my speech or read the paper. <n><n>So if I was speaking to somebody, I would write a short essay explaining my answer. <n><n>I also need to include information how. <n><n>How would I explain things to them? <n><n>Speaking out information because my audience is not going to take the time to read my paper and look at my posts on social media, so I will speak information to them. <n><n>I will summarize my information that I speak out, then I will take a picture to document what i spoke out and post it so that they

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:The president is the leader of what institution? Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		If the word was walmart, I would say it's a corporation<n><n>### Input The state of California has 120 million inhabitants. California's land mass is 660,000 square kilometers. How many people live per square kilometer?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>42 people/ 66,000 km² =3.86 people per km²<n><n>### Input<n>### Demostartion:<n>455 + 610 + 16 + 6 + 650 - 580 = 2795<n><n>### Input <n>50,000,000 people can be a large group, or a very small group. I decided to change the order of the questions and then compare the answers to try and figure out which order is better.<n><n>### Demo<n>50,050,051,88,76, 166,43<n><n>### Responce<n>If the first set is 50,05,051, where as the second set is 50500518876. I could try guessing at each character how it would affect the whole number which is not efficient. After trying various methods (adding each set to 0 which is the highest possible set if they were the lowest, adding all characters together which is the same as 18876) i'll have to conclude that there is no difference between the two sets of question<n><n>### Input (80,000 x 100,00) = 8,000, 000<n>### Demostraition<n><n>$32,000 - $16,000 = 16,00, which makes it true.<n><n>### Response<n><n>74,42, 56,01 = 8874425656<n>

So B is best because the evacuation is mandatory.<n><n>### Examples:<n>- After all the arguments, there was a mandate decided to shut down the building.<n>- The mayor issued a mandate for all citizens to wear masks in the COVID-19 crisis.<n><n>- Advisory just means a formal recommendation:<n>- The school advised students to wear masks.<n><n>- Elective is just a choice.<n>- For the elections, the elective was for President.<n>- Optional means the choice can be made to take the option or not.<n>- There's an optional class to help you with your studies.<n>

If you want to be able<n>to earn money, apply for job<n><n>### Input<n><n>A: Your neighbor needs to borrow $33. He was able to borrow $1 by standing in line and $5 by asking for a loan from his friends. He only got a $30 loan from the bank. How much does his neighbor now owe?<n><n>### Response<n>The choice that is an appropriate response to this question is B. If you stand in line to borrow money, you get a $1. <n><n>### Input <n><n>A: Your friend asked you to help her get her dog out of the mud. She was going to use toilet paper to mop up the mud. She only had to find 2 times as much toilet paper as the mud that was in the dog. She could not find any more toilet paper in the house, so she borrowed some of your toilet paper. Write the formula that she can use, including the total amount of toilet paper. <n><n>## Difinition:Formula<n><n>**Formula: (2y)...(2x),=2y(x)**: It is the product of 4 numbers (2,x,y), such as 85(2,8,5). 4 is a 3 digit number, or 4 to the power of 2 is 4^2=16. Then 8^2=64. Therefore, the product of a 4 digit number by a 3 digit number is 85(4,8,5).<n><n>### Input and Response:<n><n>Input: Your friend borrowed some money from a bank. They borrowed an amount that was 2 times a certain amount, but then they added more to that total. The grand total was the amount of $12.83. Calculate which amount was borrowed the first time, the amount that was added, and the amount that was returned. <n><n>Response: Input : (2n) + (5) Output : n + 5 Input : (2n * 3) - a + b Output : (2n * (3 - a) * (2 * b - 1)) Input: You borrowed $50. You return a certain amount of $2 with an additional $5

Choices:  A: tennis racket B: skill C: competition D: tennis court E: legs<n><n>### Response:		 A is required to be good in playing tennis.<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>If you divide 5, 10, 15, 20 by 2, you'll get 2, 5, 1, and 1 respectively. What number would you add to 1 to make it equal to 5? You could add two 1s to make it equal to five, or you could add 12. If you take that number and multiply it by 2, you get 22. What is that divisible by 3?<n>```<n><n>### Answer: 2.<n><n>### How would you approach this problem? What would be your first attempt?<n><n>### Firstly, I had to divide every item(5, 10... 20) by 2 and add 2, then I add 2 to the answer.<n><n>### What is the value of the divisor for this number sequence?  Give the number sequence and answer and then explain how you got the answer.<n><n>`6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1,...`<n><n>### Answer 2. I started by taking the sequence, `6,7,8,9,10,..., 1`, and I divided by 2. After that, I took the remainder and added 2 to get 0. Then I multiply that by `2`, and divide by 3. Finally, if the remainder is 1, I add the value of 3 to 1 and keep doing the operation to get an answer as 9.<n><n>### Lastly, I thought that the value of `6,7,...` divided by 2 got the largest number because I need to start to subtract values, so I chose 12. Then, I took the remainder, adding 2 to it, dividing by 3 and adding 3 to the answer I got. Next, I subtracted 3, and used the value as a divisor. Finally, I subtracted the value.<n>It was correct.<n><n>### The following is a question where you have to reverse the order of the numbers in a number sequence.<n><n>### 10...25,12,17...<n><n>### 6...23,16...<n><n>### The first number

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: opera B: supermarket C: building D: conference E: apartment<n><n>### Response:		<n>  - Operas are known to have people serving food at all times.<n>  - Supermarkets are known for their wide ranges of food.<n>  - Conferences generally have food provided.<n>  - There are often food stores available in apartments.<n>  - Many people do not live near any of the aforementioned locations.<n><n>### Input Choices: A: Easy B: Fresh C: Spicy D: Difficult E: Meat<n><n>### Response Choices: A: All but E B: All but D **C: All but A ** D: All but B E: All but C<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>  - All but A, Easy, Fresh, Meat, and Spicy would be difficult if any of the people who live on a farm have trouble walking.<n>  - All but B, Difficult, and Easy would be fresh if a person went on a farm.<n>  - All except C and D would be fresh if a store sold vegetables and meat.<n>  - All must be fresh if a person lived near the supermarket.<n>  - All would be impossible to be fresh if no farms existed.<n>  - All can be fresh or difficult if people are near a supermarket.<n>  A person can live on a farm in B.<n>  - All will be fresh if a store sells meat.<n>  All would be easy if they were not near a supermarket.  They could easily grow or catch fish, fruits, and vegetables.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n><n>### Input - Find the smallest three digit prime number.<n>Input: What are the smallest three digit prime numbers?<n><n>### Answer: 347<n><n>### Input<n>How many different words can be made with the letters in the word BRAIN?<n>
