Choices:  A: sneezing B: fatigue C: house clean D: feeling satisfied E: getting good grades<n><n>### Response:		 E: getting good grates<n><n>### Input :The average salary for an attorney is $185,000. This number is the mean for all individuals in the field and is calculated by adding all salary amounts and dividing by the number of people who work as attorneys. If an attorney wants to understand how much money she will make over her career, the attorney's salary at age 22 is important to consider. The average salary at age 36 is $160,000, which means that this is a reasonable expectation if an attorney works hard throughout her career. How much more do attorneys make at age 36 than they do at age 22?<n><n>### Response : $25,000<n><n>## 3. Below is an instruction that details a math problem. Write a response that accurately solves the problem.<n>### Instruction :  Let x represent the number of years Caitlin lives on Earth. If she lives on the moon for 3 years after she turns 25, how many years does Caitlin live on Earth?<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>x + 3 = 25<n>25 – 3 = x<n>22 = x<n><n>Therefore, Caitlin lives on earth for 22 years.<n><n>### Response<n>```py<n>Caitlin is on earth for 28 years. Her time on the moon adds 3 years to it. I solve for how many years Caitlin lives by setting up the equation "Caitlin's time on earth = x. (x+ 3) = 25" I then subtract the moon time to get 28<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Let x represent the number of hours that Jack can be seen in the room every day. He leaves the room and returns exactly 12 hours later on the hour.<n><n>In the morning, how long will Jack sleep? Choice A: (22 / 36)hours. Choice B: (24/36)hours<n><n>### Response <n><n>Jack sleeps for (24/3) of an hour. Answer: 8 hours<n><n>### Instructor : Let y be the total number of dollars in the safe. The criminal took $
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What do people in the same family often share? Choices:  A: brown hair B: names C: two eyes D: will E: brains<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A<n><n>### Instructions:How many items should you put in a carton if the length of the carton is 80 centimeters?<n><n>### Solution:<n>Length of Carton = 80 cm<n>Items to stack = 5 units<n>(5*16)/80 = 80 / 5 = 16 units<n><n>16 items per carton<n><n>## Instructions:What is the cost of 55 pairs of socks of the same color if the pair costs $2.50?<n><n>## Solution:<n>No of Pairs = 55<n><n>Price of each pair (Coefficient) = $2.50<n>Price of pais = 2.5<n><n>Cost = Total Price ÷ No. of pairs<n><n>Cost = [((2.5*55) ÷ 2.5) + 1.25] ÷ 2.0 = 40.375 ÷2 = $20.18<n><n>## Instruces:When is 93227 the same as 234927? Choices:(A) When the first numbers are reversed, (B) When the last 2 digits are reversed, C) When the first two digits are reversed, (D) When the digits are reversed, and the two digits before the last digit are reversed.<n><n>## Solution: A = 93228, B = 34927, C = 93247, D= 34297<n><n>If we reverse these numbers after removing last digit, we will get their inverse numbers.<n><n>Last digit is removed from both A and B to get A = 93,22<n><n>93,227 / 93,27 - 7 -> 1<n><n>B = 34,927 / 92,73 -><n><n>92,737 / 932,47 -> 12<n><n>When we reverse 9324.7<n><n>D = 342,97 / 729,34 -> 7<n><n>D = A - (Last digit from B) -> D = 93 - 7 = 86<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:James chose to not to print the cards, because he wanted to be more personal. What type of cards did he choose, instead? Choices:  A: cursive writing B: hand writing C: store bought D: online media E: hand written<n><n>### Response:		<n>James chose to hand write the card, and wanted to be more personal with the recipient. Therefore, he chose A: cursive writing<n><n>### Input  You are planning on having a party next week. You asked 5 people to come over and you told them 4 people had already responded. How many people did not respond?<n><n>### Response<n>There are 6 people.<n><n>### Input Harry took $9 to the store. If that $9 was 50% of his weekly allowance, what is Harry’s weekly allowance?<n>### Response<n>His weekly allowance is $18.<n><n>### Below are two (2) different scenarios. Choose the scenario you think requires the student to calculate the least amount of money out of pocket in the end.<n><n>### [ ]Option A: Aiden sold a cucumber he grew in his garden for $3. He then bought a 2lb bag of potatoes for $4. He was able to purchase two (2) bags of potatoes with the $3 he earned from selling his cucumber.<n><n>### Scenario B: Aiden traded one (1) can of his home grown cherry tomatoes that he purchased at the farmer’s market for one 1) stalk of his neighbor’s kale. The kale he grew in his own garden. Aiden’s kale was worth what he’d paid for it, which was 4 cents.<n>### Response<n>Option A : Aiden sold a cumber he grown is his garden for $3 and purchased a 2lbs bag of potatoes for 4$. He was able to buy 2 bags of potatoes. The least amount of money he lost was $0. <n><n>### Option B: Aiden sold one tomatoes and traded it for stalk of neighbor’s kale and got 0. Aiden’s 4 cents kale was paid for it and lost 4 cents<n><n>### Input You have $111. You are saving it by the week, and you are saving $2.50 a week, and you are planning to save it for a year. What amount did you save that week?<n>### Response: The saved money that week was $25.468 which was saved

Choices:  A"2" B"3" C"4" D"5" E"6"<n><n>### Response:"How many apples?" Choices:  B"3" C1"4" D"4" C"5" E"2" <n><n>### Input:-12 choose -2 =? Choice: A-3 B"-3/-2" C-3"-/12" D"-3" C"-/-2" E"-6" C"-/-4" <n><n>## Example Output:<n><n>| Choice | Answer  |<n>|----------|----------|<n>|A|3|<n>|B|12|<n>|C|4|<n>|D|1|<n>|E|2|<n>|<n>|A|-3|<n>|B"-3/-2|<n>|C"-3/-|<n>|E-6-|

Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>The problem is described as follows:<n><n>We have $9,997$. We can invest $1000 in bond A, $1000 to bond B, and $1000 into bond C, at which time we will have $10,000. We can only invest one of our bonds, in what order would we do so to get more interest than we have invested?<n><n>### Response<n>(20 points)<n><n>We can invest $10,097 = $9,797 – $200 (1000x2) in bond A, $2,000 bond B and $6,900 (10,001-8,001)- $9,999. We receive $9,990.<n><n><n>### Demo<n><n>Let $x$ be the initial amount and let $y$ be how much we receive. To find what x value to invest in bond B we use the equation:<n><n>$y = x * (1+i)^n$<n>where (1+i)^0 is defined as 1 since we are using exponential value, i is the yield of bond A:<n><n>$y=x (1+i) ^ 3= 10,002*9,799*1,014/32 = $9,897$<n><n>Let’s see what our initial amount must be to get in bond A the same amount of dollars from bond B<n><n>$$9,997= $9,297*(1-i)^3$$

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:A wife asks a husband to stop being married to her, what is he likely to feel even with friends? Choices:  A: happiness B: pleasure C: happy D: grief E: isolation<n><n>### Response:		The husband likely to feel happy as his friends helped him out.<n><n><n><n>### Input : The mother of three boys is considering the gifts for the holidays and she has a budget for gifts of $300 for her kids. Then you can multiply the variable by itself. Once you are done multiplying the variable, add the number to the variable to get the original value.<n><n>### Input  : Use the figure below to answer the question.<n><n>## Response  : The answer is a+b+d.<n><n>### The instructions describe several different steps. Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Solution 1:<n><n>Since it's not stated what direction she picked from the tree, we could deduce that she could either have been on either side of the tree. Therefore she should have been either in the woods or indiana.<n><n>>If she were in the woods: A and E.<n>><n>>If she were not in the woods: B and D.<n><n>#### Solution 2:<n><n>I made a few guesses from the clues to narrow the choices down to either C or E. Then I figured it'd be easier to test out the various options than to try and find the other one. If I chose any other options, I got some kind of message that led me to C or E. But I got C so I just decided to go with C. If anything, I'm sure there's another option that'd work as well.<n><n>So after trying out the various options, I narrowed down the answer to be D.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>```<n>Solve these problems in pairs and turn in your answers. <n> <n>1. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:The little girl was raised selfish, she didn't even care when she was doing what? Choices:  A: crack B: antipathy C: being mean D: disinterest E: unfeeling<n><n>### Response:		C!<n>A is selfish person, B is a feeling, C is unfeeling, D is not mean<n><n>### What is the goal of the following code block?<n><n>### Solution: The goal of the above code block is to return the largest number. I'm not sure about your response but my response is E, as it will give the largest number. I tried to execute the above block by changing E with A,B,C and D but it returned the first number.<n><n>### What else is possible to try?<n><n>### <n><n>### Doing this kind of exercise on a daily basis will help you to build your computer vision coding and problem-solving skills.<n><n>### Try to solve [this exercise](https://www.exercises.io/#/playground/RsCqb) on your laptop. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A common saying, Sam thought was, go forth.<n><n>Output: The correct answer is D, "tally back".  Tally back is a mathematical operation of reversing a number to get the original number. It can represent an iterative process to generate the same number over and over.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A is incorrect because go forth is grammatically incorrect as a common saying.<n>B is incorrect because back and forth is not a common saying.<n>C is incorrect because a tally, the process of tallying is not an action.<n>E is incorrect because you don't tally the back.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>D is the correct answer because go forth is backwards, and the second part of the mathematical operation tallying backwards.<n><n>### Other Explanation:<n>Choices: A Back B back and forth C tally back D Tally forward<n><n>### Examples<n>```<n>Inputs:<n>- A: back and forth<n>- B: back<n>- C: back and D Tally forward<n>Outputs:<n>- A is incorrect because the expression back and forth is not an iterative process. You first have to use the back function and then use the forward function in the iterative process.<n>- B is the correct answer because the back function is just a mathematical operation, so it only goes one way. It does not go back because it reverses to the original number.<n>- C is incorrect because you do not tally the back part of the mathematical operation.<n>- D is incorrect because it is the iterative process that reverses a number and the same number is used in an iterative process. Tallying is only a method of displaying the reverse of a number.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>### Find the percent of change of the numbers and multiply them together.<n>### Find the difference in years and then subtract the two different numbers of years in cents.<n>### Find number of books read by adding all the pages in the books and divide by 150.<n>### Find two numbers that sum to the number of children the two friends have.  One of the friends is a son and the other friend has 4 sisters.<n>### Multiply the amount of money by 70% and the original amount of money to get the total amount of money two friends raised.<n>

They have 5 different ways to split up this pizza.<n>Write out each way and show in a math equation how it can be split up.<n>Answer:<n>1.67 (e)<n><n>1.5 (c)<n><n>1.67 each (a)<n><n>1 (f)<n><n>2 (b)<n><n>0.66 (d)<n><n>\#1: $60 divided by 4<n>\#2: $60/4 = 10 dollars for each child.<n>\#3: $60/5 = 18333 divided with the remainder 1.<n>\#4:$14 divided by 4<n><n>Answer:<n><n>\#1.<n><n>$\frac63$ with \#2.<n><n>$\frac{\frac42}2$ with \#3.<n><n>$\frac{4$ with \#4<n>\end{code}
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Therefore, the time since the event is (current age)- (3 years) = 6 years.<n><n>### Response:"The amount of time that the patient sleeps since the first event is 3 hours." The current age is 18.<n><n>### Demo:<n>The amount of hours since the first event is (3/2)+(current age)-3= 4 hours. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:He was looking for the holiday decorations and found an old box of clothes up where? Choices:  A: attic B: trash C: loft D: closet E: box<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A 2.B 3.C 4.D 5.C<n><n>### Instructions:The last three problems are mixed multiple choice questions. Solve it by yourself.<n><n>### Question 1<n>We are asked how many eggs are needed in a mixture so that 11 pancakes can be made. We then use the recipe for 1 pancake to determine how many eggs are needed for 1 pancaek, which is 11. We divide the number of eggs (11) by how many pancakes can be done with the mixture(11), answering 1 egg per pancake.<n><n>### Challenge<n>Write the code for the challenge by yourself.<n><n>#

We thus calculate the function's value for each possible position and the bed position that has the lowest value was the one we were looking for. This works because we know that bed number 1 is in front of the house's front door and bed number 5 is behind the house's back door.<n><n>

Then take 120 and add 1 to make 121, take 121 and add 2 for 123, take that and add 3 and make 126, add 4 and make 129. So, 5 x 26 would be 129.<n><n>> Note: You can't provide just a number as the response to a math problem -- you have to show how you got to that number.<n><n>### Test Out<n><n>Write at least 5 responses.<n>

The program should not ask the user for input.<n><n>#### Input: Input a single hypothesis statement as a string. See examples for an acceptable phrase structure.<n><n> <n>#### Output: Choose a 'yes' or 'no' answer to the hypothesis based on the text inputted by the user.<n><n>#### Hint: Use a 'for' loop for readability and efficiency of code. Use'strings.isalpha' to check if a word is a string starting with capital letter.<n><n>#### Example:<n>> A for loop can be used in Python to check if an input sentence meets the criteria of your program. <n>> If all inputs do, the for loop makes the execution of your code easier, and more efficient.<n>Input = "The sky is blue" <n>> The program then checks and prints out a 'YES' if the inputed statement is true, and a 'NO' if the statement is false.<n>####  Outcome: The program should:<n><n>>1. Read the inputted hypothesis.<n>>2. Choose a 'yes or no' to answer the statement.<n><n>#### HINT:<n>Input the code into a programming language of your choice (e.g. python). The function should be recursive, meaning it should call itself upon a recurrence.<n><n>```<n>using System;<n><n>namespace RecursiveFunctions<n>{<n>    class Program<n>    {<n>        static void Main(string[] args)<n>        {<n>            try<n>            {<n>                int value = AddNumbers(5, 7);<n>                Console.WriteLine(value);<n>                Console.ReadKey();<n>            }<n>            catch(Exception ex)<n>            {<n>                Console.WriteLine("Exception caught: {0}", ex.Message);<n>                Console.Write("Press Enter...");<n>                Console.ReadLine();<n>            }<n><n>        }<n><n>        static int AddNumbers(int a, int b)<n>        {<n><n>            return AddNumbers(++a, b);<n>        }<n>       }<n>   }<n> }<n>```<n><n>## C++ Question<n><n>> Write a function, addNumbers, that can be called by adding all the numbers in an array (or two-dimensional array). After the inflator valve, the detector system deploys an inflation manifold.  The inflation manifold pumps a gas, such as nitrogen, into the airbag to activate the device.  An airbag deployment is a complex series of actions that takes place within milliseconds.<n><n>###Response<n>The airbag inflation is the next step in a car’s safety airbag sequence.<n><n>###Input :<n>3 friends were walking towards a store. 21/3 minutes apart. Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n><n>### Response:		<n>The most common places where they traditionally get information about world are newspaper and television. Nowadays, social media is also an alternative for them to gather information about the world.<n><n><n>Input: How were the news stories about the Titanic’s sinking initially described? Answer: A: tragic B: a disaster C: a calamity D: a wreck<n><n>### Response<n>There is no single cause of the Titanic sinking. However, some factors have been identified to contribute to the events that had occurred on the Titanic ship that night. According to one article, the main cause were that 1) Titanic’s waterproofed compartments were not fully used, 2) its lifeboats were deemed to be adequate at the time of its departure from England, 3) the ship had not been equipped with enough lifeboats and equipment for lifesaving, and 4) the ship’s lookout staff reported not having sufficient lookouts that night (A Titanic, E1).  Another article identifies two major reasons for the ship sinking: 1) The ship’s crew failed to fully implement the orders on launching all lifeboats when they were still there, and 2) the ship was built to carry 25% more passengers than the number of lifeboats available (A Titanic: History, E2).<n><n><n>Input: On what part of the ship did the Titanic sink? Answer: A: its hull B: its superstructure<n><n>### Response The Titanic sank at its bottom side, which includes its hull and superstructure. The reason is that it has three compartments which are sealed with watertight, however only one compartment was damaged on the bottom. When this compartment was infiltrated by water, water flowed throughout several compartments and damaged other compartments as it flowed downward. When the other watertight compartments were also damaged and water got in, Titanic sank very quickly (A Titanic Sinking: The Complete Story, E3).<n><n><n>InputHow many days passed between the sinking of the Titanic and the delivery of a box of personal effects from first-class passenger Edith Haisman to her husband in Australia? Answer: A: two days B:

If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you look at your shadow from the ground, you will see your shadow cast on the ground directly in front of you. To find your shadows relative position to the surface of the ground, you can use the formula:<n><n>`V = H + W`<n>Where V is the distance of your shadow from the surface of the ground (W) in feet (H is the distance of object on which your shadow appears (eg ground))<n><n>Because we want to know the surface of the building (not the ground), our formula will look something like this:<n><n>`S = B + L`<n><n>`S` = Sides of building (B) inches<n>`L` = length of the longest shadow (124 inches)<n><n>With the above formula, the shadow is half way between the front of the building and the length of the shadow. Which is 62 inches from the front of the building.<n><n>If you look at a bridge, the shadows length would not be the same as a building. Since the building has a flat surface, the shadow will remain on only one side of that surface. However, the bridge has uneven surfaces. For this reason, the shadow of a bridge will have multiple surfaces it casts on.<n><n>### Input 2: A bridge has 226 feet of length and 1 5/7 feet wide. <n>If it has a support post at every 5 feet, how many support posts are on the bridge?<n><n>### Response<n>The bridge is a two-column bridge (the second column is attached at the end of the bridge). There are 226 supports which are 5 feet apart (there are not 5 supports between columns). Therefore the number of supports is 62/1 which is 62.<n>

Choices:  A: learn about subject B: learn new C: find truth D: is bliss E: judge<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A and C<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the table with all missing answers<n><n>### Instructons:The numbers in square brackets describe the order in which they occur.  Each step is part of a greater, linear sequence of processes<n><n>### Instruitons:In the numbered spaces, name the process followed, and name the next step in the process as instructed.<n><n>### Input:[15] A family goes apple picking on a Saturday. They pick three varieties of apples, a red one, a yellow one, and a green one.  They take a red apple, a yellow apple, and a green apple home. After coming back from the field, [20] they discover that a little bird had eaten the yellow apple they took with them, so now they have two apples. [24] The mom wants to make some pies with the three apples, so she asks each member of her family to give one of their three apples.  The grandpa, the mom, and the child all give one of their three, but the dad doesn’t want to give up any of his apples, so he ends up keeping all three of his. In all, the family ends up with two apples. Explain what happened to each of the original three apples from the field.<n>ANS:The original three apples from picking were: red, green, yellow.   (step#15)<n><n>-First the number 15 came, there were four apples in total.<n>-Then the number 19 arrived, two of the apples were consumed (two apples)<n>-Next, the number 24 appeared, three of the apples were taken home (two apples)  <n><n>ANS:The yellow apple, since the red apple was consumed and the yellow apple disappeared, the dad is the only one who still has the yellow apple (green apple) and the green apple is now the one eaten (red apple). The mom and grandpa's apples were combined. (step#24)<n><n>-First, the number 20 arrived, three of the appes were taken home. (green and red)<n>-Next, after that the number 24 came, and the green was eaten (now has red)<n>-After that the

Choices:  A: company B: telephone netwok C: airport D: wires E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n>B (telephone network)<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A: A B: B C: C D: D E: E<n><n>### Outputs:<n>A: B C:C D:D E:E<n><n>### Input Explanation:<n>A: If an electrical item won’t power on (turn “on”), checking the batteries is a good initial test. Check batteries for power (is the indicator light on?). Replace batteries and test again. If the batteries are good, check the connection (plug in the electrical item and test for power). If the electrical equipment will not power on, what connection is the next thing to check?<n><n>### Output Explanation:<n>B) The next thing to check is the telephone network. Use a phone to call someone; if the call is not answered, check the phones or the jack on the wall.<n><n>### Input and Output explanation:<n>C) Check the circuit breakers. If one of the circuit breakers flips when power is first turned on, it can cause the equipment to stop.<n><n>### If this connection is powered, what’s next?<n>D) If the power isn’t working in one device, it can mean that there’s something wrong with the freeway. Check the freeway for a problem.<n><n>### Output explanation: (E) If checking the power is not effective, it could be the airport. The airport controls the power and is connected to the other places.<n><n>### In your own words:<n>When a device doesn't work, check the connection (if it works, it isn't the connection) and if it doesn't work, it's a different connection (freeway, airport, telephone network). If the device is still broken after that, the power is bad and so is the wires (circuit breakers).<n><n>### Question:<n>What were you not able to do with this task?<n><n>I was not able to get the prompt correct (the explanation was not the output).<n><n>### Feedback:<n>I have added the instructions; they were deleted before.<n><n>### Challenging Problems (optional):<n>- Input: 50 students were in a school club for 1 month. It had been a long and busy day, so all you wanted to do that day was relax and chill in front of the TV. But after your mom called and said that the house needed to be cleaned, you were at a loss. Even if you were to clean the house from top to bottom, you were still going to have to do school chores when your sister got home. Your mom thought you could clean for half an hour; she told you that after you’d cleaned the house, you could take a 15-minute break, then come back and finish cleaning. That seemed like a great idea, but you had an idea that it would be more efficient if you put away the cleaning products (such as vacuum cleaner, paper towels, cleaning solutions, cloth, mop, etc.) as the house was being cleaned, without cleaning them first. If you put them away when they were used, you wouldn’t have to worry about cleaning them again. Then, the house could always be clean at your next visit. Your sister seemed impressed by your idea. She believed that since you could clean the house in such a short time, your 15-minutes-break would be plenty of time to finish school chores. But your mom had another problem: one of your sister’s friends wanted to stay over and she knew you were probably busy. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:James went to the best steakhouse outside of the South.  Where is James? Choices:  A: dairy farm B: texas C: building D: michigan E: florida<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Why?:dairy farm<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Demostration<n><n>In the first problem, we know that the difference in ages between Richard & Hurley is 2. We take that and double it to get 4. Then we add 40 to that to get 44.  Richard & Hurley are 44 years apart.  <n><n>In the second problem, we know that each time Pablo reads a page he gets a penny. After reading his books he has 15 pages left to read to save the $15 and have 3 pennies left. He must have read 18 pages <n><n>In the third problem, we know that for the first 15 pages, the cost of the book is $10. Since we are making a difference of 2, we add 2 onto the book fee for it to be divided into 6 people. That would be $30. The 6 people divided it by 2 to get 50 dollars. Now that we have the $500, we take out 50 which means we're left with $450.  Since the total cost for the group is $170 now that Brad is out, he does not need to pay the remaining $30 since he had 1/450.<n><n>In the fourth problem, we're assuming that the $70 paid for all the items. If each gift cost $10 and there were 4 different items, the 60 eggs equaled 60+40+30+20+10 divided by $70 total and multiplied by $60 to get the first five gifts that were $10.  The total number of gifts minus the sixth gift that was $70. The sixth gift was a sixth gift in price, not a number. That's why it's a different number since it is not divided by $70.<n><n>In option e, the total amount of money made by people for eBay is 3000.

Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## <n><n>![Answer](/media/assets/1070-solution.jpeg)<n><p>12</p><n>```js<n>var answer = input.charAt(2) * 10 + input.charAt(3);<n>```<n><n>### Input description:The difference in ages between Richard an Hurley is 2o. If Hurley is years old, what are thier combined ages years from now?<n>```js<n>const a1 = 'hurley';<n>const a1 = 14;<n>const b = 40;<n>```<n><n>## <n>![Question](/media/assets/4011-solution.jpeg){:.width :.600 }<n><p>1</p><n>```<n>input.length <= 10;<n>for (; input.length > 0; ){<n>// Read one character from input.<n>char c = input.charAt()<n>// If the input character is 'a',...<n>if ( c == a ) then a1++<n>if ( a1 == 10 ) then let l = input.indexOf('\n')<n>// Print one line of output starting with <a><n>print('A' + l + a1)<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Input Description:Pablo's Mother agrees to pay him c for every page he reads he plans to save the money to buy some candy he always checks out books that <n>matter he went to the store an bought $ c with remaining c he went back to the book store and made even with the candy. The remaining cost would <n>leave would be split between the 6 friends<n><n>## <n>Input:The cost of the car is 1700 the cost is 70 the cakes. The remaining amount will be split equally between the 6 friends.<n>```js<n>var remainder = 70;<n>const b1 = 0.25;<n>for (; remainder < 1700; ){<n>remainder = remainder + (input.charAt() * b1)<n>print(String(remainder))<n>}<n>```<n>![Question](/media//assets/4012-solution.jpeg.500)<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		What do customers do to complete their purchases?<n><n>### Input<n>What is the total price of all of Harper’s purchases?<n><n>What is the difference between the price of apples and potatoes?<n><n>How much does Harper spend on cheese?<n><n>### Response<n>Difference: (Apples – Potatos)<n><n>Price of  Apples:<n><n>Price of  Potatoes:<n>How much does apples cost?<n><n><n><iframe src="https://www.quillbot.com/embed.html?language=de&url=https://github.com/alexpilot/CS/blob/master/Homework2/QuillBot/QuillBot.md" width="100%" height="1100px" scrolling="" margin="1-padded"></iframe><n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		<n>  C<n>  4<n>### Input:Which of the following does not contribute to someone’s self-esteem? Choices : A: Money B: Talent C: Appearance D: Friends E: Family<n><n>### Response<n>  B<n>  1<n>### Input: You and your best friend have a Netflix party and you both watch a movie, the two of you paid $17.17 for the movie and split the costs equally. Your friend was planning on having a slice of pizza while watching. If the pizza costs $6, when he was ordering did he get his order wrong?<n><n>#Input:<n>An artist painted 40% of a picture. If the total cost of painting the picture was $240, how much did the artist make painting 40% of the picture?<n><n>#Response: <n>48.00<n><n>[Code]: https://code.com/<n>[Grade level(s):]: 2-3<n>[Programming Language(s):]: JavaScript<n>[Level of Difficulty:]: Intermediate<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>### Output<n><n>```<n><n>```<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>Write a program that will ask the user to enter a list of integers. The program will display the average of the list.<n><n>### Input <n>``` <n>Enter a list of numbers  (blank indicates end of list)<n>1 2 3<n>```<n><n>## Demostration<n>```<n>5<n>=> 3.33<n>```<n><n>```shell<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>echo "Enter a list of numbers"<n>read list<n><n>for i in $list; do<n>	num=$(echo "$i" | bc)<n>	#echo "$i"<n>	sum=$(( $sum + $num ))<n>	#echo "$sum"<n>done<n><n>avg=$(( $sum / ${#list} ))<n><n>echo "$avg"<n>```<n><n>## Output<n>``` <n>Enter the list   (blank indicates end of entry)<n>1 2<n>```<n><n>[Shell Script]: https://www.shellscriptingonline.com<n>[Level of Dificulty]: Intermediate<n><n>[Khan Academy

Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n><n>### Response:		A: revealing information<n><n>### Input<n>It is December 31, you are 24 years old, and you want to save $1000 for your 45th birthday. Your boss gives you a small raise for your great work and you are now earning $400 per month after taxes. Every year, your investment earns 6% interest compounded monthly and you contribute $150 from your salary every month. The months of January and September cost 0% interest and all other months cost 3% interest. How much money will be in your account on March 1, 2025?<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is $2455. If we take one year (48 months) and divide it into 45, we will have 0.9607 years leftover. By subtracting the months with 0% interest, we have 0.91 years left. Then, we multiply the remainder by the interest rate from the leftover months (3%) to get the interest for the remaining months, which is 0.279 years. To solve this in the most simple way, I multiplied 0.91 by 0.008 and I got 0.0784. The annual interest of $185 was divided by 12 and divided by 0.0774 (the number of years). $185 / 0.07574 = $331.22. Then, I multiplied every single amount that I had already given by 0.33, and I subtracted the result from the total ($3240). $3510 - $133 = $3377.23. Lastly, I subtracted the yearly interest ($185 + $45) from the amount ($3412.23). $3412.53 - $364 = $2455<n>### Input:Given the following salary schedule, determine the total amount of each type of payment.<n><n>### Response-Answer:<n>| Age | Salary | <n>|-------|----------|<n>|10-15|$400| <n>|16-20|$

Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer from the options provided but in a different order.<n>```python<n>answer = input("What eastern state is home of mountain ") # A:, B:, C:, D:, And E:<n>if answer.lower() == "pennsylvania":<n>    answer = "Mountain: Mountain_in_pennsylvania"<n>elif answer.lower() == 'pictures':<n>    answer = "mountain: mountain_in_pictures"<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		If I need deoderant, I go to the grocery store. The grocery store would be the best choice because it contains many products that would be useful in the future, especially food. But the medicine cabinet would be a good choice and not the kitchen. The kitchen would only give you kitchen utensils. The medicine chest would also only give you medicine supplies.  The armpits would result in body odor which would not be fun for the future.<n><n>### Input If a teacher gives out 100 tests, but allows 2 wrong answers per test, how many tests are graded as wrong?<n><n>### Response You have to count for each test. So if there are 100 tests then there is a total of 200 answers possible. The answers are given 2 wrong answers per person so 100 tests are graded as incorrect.<n><n>### Below you will find a list of statements related to different subjects. <n><n>### Input<n>A. 2.5 = 25%<n>B. 0.3 = 30%<n>C. 10 = 10 percent<n>D. 0.2 = 20%, 0.4 = 40%<n>E. 0.8 = 80%, 0.2 =10%<n><n>### Response<n>All of them are equal because they have a base value of 10 % with a varying answer<n><n>### Question: A grocery store has 60 rolls of toilet paper available. 8 rolls have been used to wipe the bathroom floor and none remain to be stacked on the shelves. Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Correct:<n>A.<n><n>#### Incorrect:<n>B.<n><n>C.<n><n>D.<n><n>E.<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Input<n>Input: A pizza costs $3.75. Jenny, Shiya, and Alyssa paid individually. Shiya ate half a pizza. Jenny wants 3/7ths of a pizza. And Alyssa wants 5/7ths of her individual portion. How much did each person pay?<n><n>### Response<n>Incorrect: If the three individuals all pay $3.75, why would the total payment be $7.25?<n><n>Correct:<n>A. Jenny 2.04 dollars<n>B. Shiya 1.09 dollars<n>C. Alyssa 1.2<n><n>#### Incorrect<n>A. Jenny ate 1.21<n>Shiya ate 0.63<n>Alyssa ate 1.67<n><n>#### Correct<n>A. Jenny eats 1.04<n>Shiya eats 0.54<n>Alyssa eats 1.47.<n><n><n>### Note:<n><n>This section should be written in the correct language, not in a mix.<n><n>### Input 2<n>Input: John wants to do a special gift this year by giving a card. Each card costs $5. He is buying 5 cards to give to his 5 family members. How much will he pay for the total number of cards?<n><n>### Correct<n>John pays $25<n><n>### Incorrect<n>John pays $20<n>Correct Answer: Total card payment = $5 * 5 = 25 dollars.<n><n>### Question 3<n>Input 3: John goes into the store to purchase 4 items. He knows that the items are priced according to the following system:<n><n>$ 0.43: for every single dollar that you spend, you get 0.043 toys.<n><n>$ 04.93: for every single four dollars that you spend, you can purchase any 0.96 toys available in the toy section and the first 10 you buy are free.<n><n>$17.89:

Would you like a demonstration of calculating combined ages?")<n>    <n>    if answer == "yes" or answer == "Y":<n>        print("Sure would. I'll get right on that for you. ")<n>    <n>    elif answer == "no" or answer == "N":<n>        print("Well, then. Is there anything else you need help with? ")<n>    <n>    else:<n>        break<n><n>#<n># This code will be run before we start answering the users questions<n># the main program here will run awhile statement which will run the user's input<n># in a while statement we will be checking to see if the input has an answer of yes or no<n># If it does not then we will be exiting the loop or else we will continue with the programs loop<n>#<n><n>answ = ""<n>answ2 = ""<n>answ3 = ""<n>answ4 = ""<n>answ5 = ""<n>answ6 = ""<n>answ7 = ""<n>answ8 = ""<n>answ9 = ""<n>answ10 = ""<n>answ = "" #<n>while True:<n>    <n>    answer = input()<n>    <n>    if( answer == "yes" ):<n>        answer = "answer.py"<n>        <n>    else:<n>            break<n><n>print("This is Python Tutter. We now enter the user's input")<n><n>#<n># We now start with the

The chicken that is 1/3 meat is $11.21<n><n>B. The chicken that contains 10% meat is $112.85<n><n>C. The chicken that measures 1/4 meat is $4.79<n><n>D. The chicken that has 17% meat is $26.46<n><n>E. The chicken that cost 16% contains 100% meat<n><n>Answer: Option (A)/<n><n>### Reasons:<n><n>Option A states this: The chicken that is one-third meat is 11.21 (that is 2/3, so you take 1/3 of $11.20 which gives you 11.20 divided by.3 which equals $11.29 11.29 times 3 is 34.07 and 11.2 + 34.08 is now equal to 45.27 1/4 equals the 45.29 and 16% of the chicken is.3 which equals 34.09963744764903880859375<n><n>### Output:<n><n>I got 11.2% meat and 16% feathers so 16% to 11.2%. This gives you 3.94 in feathers. Then.26. If you add the 16% to the total you would get 84% in total. 3.94+84% is

B and C M: Choices: O: None of these.<n><n>### Responses:<n>The correct answer is D: All of these responses (A, C, and B). This is because the question was unclear, but from the given choices, the question asks about the friends and not about the group they're in.

The digit sum are:<n><n>2789 : 2+7+8+9 = 26<n><n>3742 : 3+7+4+2 = 16<n><n>5823 : 5+8+2+3 = 18<n><n>The last  two digits are equal to the digit sum.<n><n>However, 2789 has the first and the last two digital value the same: 7.<n><n>2784 : 2+7=9<n><n>6239 : 6+2+3 =11<n><n>3745 : 3+7=10<n><n>5877 : 5+8=13<n><n><n><n>### Input	: What are the common values in a group of 3, five digit numbers?<n><n>### Response <n><n>What are the common value in a group of 2 digit numbers?<n><n>#### Explanaton:<n><n>The three five digit numbers I input are 4876, 2593, 8733.<n><n>When I count the last two  digits which are equal to the digit_sum, the second and the third digits are the same: 3 and 3, so the digit sum is 6.<n><n>The first and the last digits are different, so no.<n><n>### Difference : How much different are the two numbers?<n><n>## Input :  Answer: 1267<n><n>### Response :<n><n>The sum of the two digit numbers in the first and second rows is 3669.<n><n>The sum of their digit_sum are 6 and 6. How many apples, potatoes and combinations of apple and potatoes does each group receive?<n><n>### Response :<n>One apple and two potatoes are divided into seven equal groups. Let us assume the groups are A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6 and A7. To receive the equal distribution of the apple, **it's** a simple math calculation,<n><n>$$A1 = {1 \over 7}$$<n>$$A2={1 \over 7} - {1 \over 2}$$<n>$$A3={1 \over 4}$$<n>$$A4={1 \over 2} - {1 \hbox{ apple} \over 7}$$ <n>$$A5={1 \over 1} - {2 \hbox{ apples} \over 7} + {1 \hbox{ potato} \over 7 } $$<n>$$A6={1 \over 3} - {2 \over 7}\space\hbox{apples} - {1 \times 2 \hbox{ app/pot} \over 7 }\space\hbox{} $$<n>$$A7={1 \over 6} -  {1 \times 4 \hbox{ apple/potato} \over 21}$$ <n>We see clearly that each group received $\frac{1}{7} $ apple and <n>$${{1} \over{21}} \times {3} \hbox{ apple/ pot} \rightarrow <n>\begingroup \textstyle \binom{3+1}{1}=\frac{6+1}{2}=3+\frac{2}{2}=3+\binom{1}{1}={{1}

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:What should the bean bag chair sit on? Choices:  A: house B: den C: family room D: wood E: floor<n><n>### Response:		(D)<n>

There is no need to capitalize 'he' since it is already a pronoun. (Prices like "He," they are not used to show possession unless you are using them in a poem.)<n><n>## Instrucitons<n><n>Write a sentence (15-20 words) that is a response to each of the statements below using the correct capitalizations and punctuation. This question must be answered with a separate sentence.<n><n>### Pronoun Usage<n><n>### Statements:<n> <n>We need to bring the lawn mower.<n> <n>- Who is ‘we’?<n> <n>- Can they be left out of this sentence?<n> <n>- Doesn’t ‘we’ stand for a plural group (plural person)?<n> <n>- What are they referring to?<n> <n>- What is the word that they have in common with ‘the car’?<n> <n>The dog is nice. <n> <n>- Is ‘you’ incorrect?<n> <n>- Should there be no object pronoun?<n> <n>- Is it a subject or an object pronoun?<n>

You will start off with $3000. You will not have $60 in 50 days, giving an answer of $3000 and $3200.<n>

Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Dem:<n>### Answer:<n>```<n>$4200<n>```<n><n>### Input <n>- In an average group of 25 people, how many should you expect to answer? (Choices:  A: 20 B: 15 C: 15 D:10 E: 5)<n>### Dem: <n><n>### Input<n>```<n>500<n>-50%<n>```<n>### Response<n>```<n>$250<n>```<n>### Input:<n>```<n>S = 1000 W + 100<n>```<n># Input<n>```<n>3/4<n>```<n><n>- Output:<n>```<n>0.75<n>```<n>### Solution<n><n>1. Create an array of integers in range 1..8<n>2. Iterate over the array<n>3. For each integer, calculate it's divisors ie: the numbers it's divisible by<n>4. Print out the list of the divisors for each integer in the list <n>5. Print out the sum of the divisors<n>6. Calculate the average divisor<n>7. Print out the average divisor<n><n>```<n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n>    List<Integer> list = new ArrayList<>(8);<n>    for(int i=1; i<=8; i++){<n>        for(int j=1; j<=i; j++){<n>            list.add(j);<n>        }<n>    }<n>    PrintDivisors(list);<n>}<n>private static void PrintDivisors(List<Integer> divisors){<n>    for(int divisor : divisors){<n>        System.out.println(divisor);<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>```<n>0.25<n>```<n>```<n>5<n>```<n>```56833<n>```<n>### Instruction<n><n>After 10 days, the total cost of gasoline added up to $125. If you want to cool down you need to get rid of the hot stuff and that might take place through  A: loss of the hot stuff from your body that he has been holding  B: loss of the hotness of your body and that may take place for revenge or expansion or relaxation or calm down D. All answers except A are tricks!<n><n>### Tips:<n>1. If you add two numbers, then the result is in a different line.

Choices:  A: costly B: captive C: contained D: paying E: caught<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n><n>import ast<n><n><n>def answer(q, ans):<n><n>    '''<n>    q = question<n>    ans = answer<n>    '''<n><n>    for i in range(1,26):<n>```<n>i = i + 1<n><n><n>if (i %15 == 15):<n>```<n>print(f'Answer is {i}')<n>```<n><n>if i!= ans :<n>```<n>    if str(ans[0]) == str(q[0]) and str(ans[-1]==0) and int(str(ans[-1]))!=int((str(q[-1]['Q']))):<n>        answer(q,'A')<n><n>    elif str(ans[0]), str(q[i]), str(ans[-1])==str(q[0])==str(q[-1])=='None' and (str(ans[-1])!='None'):<n>        answer(q, 'B')<n><n>    elif ans[-1]=='None' and int(str(q[i]))==(int(str(ans[-i])!='None' and int(Q(i,i+len(q)-1))):<n>        answer( q, 'C')<n><n>    else:<n>        answer(q,"D")<n>            <n>if i == ans:#if ans is the input answer   <n>        print(f'Answer:({ans})')<n>        end <n>"""<n>"""This function allows you to use this script as a game"""

If every 30 minutes hiking up is 75% faster then hiking down, how many minutes does Kayla go hiking down?<n>### Response The distance the two hike up and down from start to finish is the same. Kayla and her friend walk up and down 300m a min for a total of 60 min. At the end of 60 minutes they have covered a total distance of 300m from the start of their walk.

The group of people includes three girls, two boys, and one grandparent. One person is picking up all the people who were not at the airport and are driving 20 hours. She decides to set one car as the “back-up car,” which means it will always follow the person with the youngest child. She also sets two cars as “lead cars,” which mean they will always follow each other closely. If she does not follow all the carpool rules, how many hours after 9:00 PM will the youngest child be dropped off at home?<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write the next correct code block to correctly complete the task. Explain why you chose the response you did for all answers.<n><n>### Task 1<n><n>### Your response (code block)<n>A: 10 hours<n>B: 9 hours<n>C: 12 hours<n>D: 15 hours<n><n>### Instructor explanation<n>The car is picked up and dropped off at home at 5:05 each night.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>A: $80 B: $60 C: $40 D: $180<n><n>### Your Response (code block)<n>D: $180,<n>A: $880,<n>C: $400,<n>B: $640<n><n>### Instuctor explanation<n>The difference in wages is $1160.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Input<n><n>In this task, we want to add these two values and get their sum.<n><n>```<n>In the beginning, let’s try to find out possible sum of values.<n>First 1+2, next 7+12, then 7+14 etc.<n>So we get:<n>21<n><n>So we can find that possible sum is at least 21.<n>Now, let’s check how many possible values less then 21.<n>So we try the smaller one.<n>6

The student's number line is 0 to 10.  The score board has every team's number from 1 to 100. If the team number 96 lost, then the team number 97 would advance to the next round. Teams that lose a match are removed from the tournament.<n>- The first match in the round robin would be 3 vs 92 and then the second match would be 3 vs  93 and the third match would be 3 against  94 and so on until teams  96 and  97 are removed from the round-robin tournament.  After each match, if a team wins, then the next match would be the team on the same position, but if a team loses, then the next match is the next team below.<n>- First, there will be 30 teams (each team consists of 10 students) in the tournament. 5 matches after the first match, there would only be teams with numbers 1 to 5,  next the two winning teams remain in the tournament, and the losing team is removed. 7 matches after the first match only the two winning teams

Write a Python program that correctly completes the task.<n><n>### Inputs:Write a statement that asks the user to enter information.<n><n>### Outputs:A statement that will display the results of the task when necessary; a statement that will print "Good job!!!" when the desired results are received.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:  What is 86.436 rounded to two decimal places?<n>**Answers: 86.44**<n><n>Input: What is 123.145 rounded to two decimal places<n>**Answers (from Python): 123.2**<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Lesson Summary:<n><n>### Review Questions:<n>### Challenge Questions:<n><n>```python<n><n>### Input<n>print("Enter data to be rounded to two decimal places")<n>roundnum = input()<n>###  Output<n>output = round(roundnum, 2)<n>###  Task<n>### If the input is less than one, the round number will be 0<n>### If the number input is already two decimal places, the round number will equal the input number<n>if (roundnum == 0):<n>    numoutput = 0<n>else: <n>    numoutput = roundnum <n><n>### Explanation <n>print("The rounded number is ", numoutput)<n><n>### Solution <n><n>if (roundnum < 1):<n>    numoutput == 0<n>else:  <n>    numoutput = str(roundnum)<n><n>print("The rounded value:

Pilastre decided to use a sprocket, a small metal wheel that ran on a chain, attached to the front of his plane to act as a coaster. Otto Lilien wanted to do the same thing, and also decided to attach his plane to the ground with a sprocket. However, Pilastre used a bigger sprocket than Lilien did. Choices: A: 65 B:89 C: 105 D: 110 E: 112<n><n>### Instructions : Use the equation to solve for z<n><n>### Demos : (2x)^3+(2x)^3 - (3x^(2) - x - (2x^3 - 7x)*x^2<n><n>### Response ; (x^2-1)*(x^2-2) - 2x - (2x^2 - 3)<n><n>### The last digit of 2456789098 does not give an answer of 10 when the product of the last digit of each number is multiplied together. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Where can someone keep a digital file? Choices:  A: suitcase B: filing cabinet C: computer D: desk drawer E: cloud<n><n>### Response:		<n>The appropriate word is:<n>A: suitcase<n>```<n><n>## Multiple Choice:<n>**Bullet Point**- Write 2 or more reasons why something shouldn't have a certain name. Your response <n>should be at least two full sentences or a single paragraph.<n><n>### Bullet Point:<n>Should a dog named Koda be called a puppy? ________<n>Write at least two reasons supporting each choice.<n><n>1.<n>a.  A dog is a dog and a puppy is a dog.<n>b.  Yes, because it means small<n>c.  No, because a dog is a dog even if it is grown<n><n>2.<n>a. Koda is big and strong, not small and weak.<n>b.<n>c.<n><n>3.<n>a. Kodas are old, not young or small.<n>b.<n><n>### Response<n>12.<n>a.<n>b.<n>```<n><n># Write an Instruction<n>Write a question that describes a task. Below are two sample questions to help you write an <n>instruction.<n><n>### Sample 1:<n><n>## Sample 2:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Type:** Response Question<n><n>### Response Question Sample:<n><n>### Example 1<n>In the story, which boy is more mature?<n><n>### Example answer for 1:<n>**Gabe** - because he stays on topic<n><n>### Example Answer for 2:<n>**Gabe and Tayvon** - because <n><n>### Responsible for: <n><n>### Response for:<n><n>### Response Topic:<n><n>### Type:<n><n>### Bulletin Board:<n>### Write the task below<n>### <n><n><n>### Answer 1<n>Answer the questions below!<n>What animal is taller, a rhinoceros or a giraffe?<n>What kind of pet has five legs?<n><n>### Answer<n>A: a giraffe is taller than a rhinoceros<n><n>B: a goat is the only animal that has five legs.

However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Explain a given response that may vary from the requested one<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostrate:<n><n>Input:<n><n>The difference in ages between Richard<n>and Hurley is 23<n>If Hurley is 15 then how old are they combined 28 years from now?<n><n>Response:<n><n>The answer is 217 years old.<n><n>However, Hurley is a boy and when a boy reaches the age of 40 which is the year 2034 then Richard would turn 85 which is the exact age difference 44 years.<n><n>### Expect More, Get more<n><n>In addition to how you demonstrate you will:<n>*   Write the requested response<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>Input 1:<n><n>You need to make $320 in the next month. If you take a week and spend no more than $100 then you will have $15 left to spend.<n>The remainder amount of dollars per week will be the dollar amount you will need to take home each week.<n><n>Input 2:<n><n>Ali went to the store and spent $28.  After that, she found that she was short $8.  The cashier at the store knew that Ali will only go to the store one more time.<n>How much does the cashier know that Ali will have to spend on her next visit to the store?<n><n>Input 3:<n><n>Joe is able to do 20 pushups.  Tim is able to do 4 more pushups.  How many pushups can Joe do now?<n><n><n>## The Skills You Need: Answering Multiple Choice

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer<n>In order to know which you have, you should first explain what each of these terms are. <n>A: Morning person is when you are someone who is a "morning person," or someone who wakes up in the morning happily to enjoy a day that doesn't start after noon.  <n>B: An early bird is someone who awakens very early in the morning to start their day.<n>C: I'd hear a Lark at sunrise. <n><n>### Input<n>You're trying to make the perfect birthday cake.  You have a box that cost 15 cents and you have a bunch of pans that you can use but each pan costs you 18 cents to make the cake.  Each pan can make you 20 cakes. How many pans would you need to make 50 cakes?<n><n>### Response<n>The first step would be to figure out the total cost of the pans. After determining the total cost, you would be more likely to purchase the least amount of pans to make each cake without spending more than you initially planned.<n><n>Total Cost:.90 (15 cents + 18 cents * 20)<n><n>50 *.90 = 45<n><n>45 = 25 + 20<n><n>Thus 20 would be the minimum amount of pans you would need to make the cakes without spending more than your initial plan.<n><n>### Input 1: I am thinking of two numbers. I double my first number, and add 10. Then I subtract my first number from my second number. What does the author mean by that? Choices: A: Rules only exist to help outsiders. B: Rules help society keep order and peace. C: Rules help society reach an unspoken consensus. D: Rules help society live in harmony together. E: Rules help society stay on the same page with each other.<n><n>- A: The author implies in this statement that society would descend into outright chaos if not for those rules we obey in society. The laws exist for our own benefit and to keep society smoothly running.<n><n>### Response answer:B<n><n>### Instructon:Answer the above multiple-choice question given in the instruction.<n><n>### Requirement:Write a response that appropriately answers the request.<n><n>Answer A: "Rulers of the state are more frequently conspicuous for their vices than their virtues. Rulers should be guided by the rules of ________. " In this quote, the author is referring to the morals of society. He is implying in this way that those who are in power, leaders, should have the best interest of society in mind and should take guidance from society’s rules, not the other way around.<n><n>### Examples:<n>Input: It is important to use your resources, especially your brain, to the best of its ability.<n>

During 24 minutes, there are 38 vehicles that go down Main Street.  How many streets are there on Main Street?<n>- A restaurant sells 27 boxes of cookies per table.  At some point during the day, the restaurant sells 2,305 boxes of cookies.  How many tables are in the restaurant?<n>- A girl's clothing has 5 colors.  There are 123 pieces of clothing that have 2 colors.  The average number of colors on each piece of clothing is 2.3. If the clothing has 4 colors, it will increase the average by 33%.  How many pieces of clothing do only have 2 colors?<n>- There are 24 boxes that are labeled 'a'.  These boxes must be stacked on top of 24 other boxes that are labeled Z.  There is a total of 20% of the boxes labeled 'a' that are on top of the Z.  If there is 20% of 'a' on top of Z, how many boxes are there that are labeled 'Z'?<n>- There are different colors of shirts, and pants that are in the store.  There are 22,678,000 total shirts and pants in the store.  If there are only 4,452 shirts and pances that are green, a certain number of shirts and pans that are green are 4.4/2,358.  How many shirts and pents are there in the store that are green?<n><n>#### Answer:<n>- A) The difference between Richard and Hurley are 16 years old. A. Hurley is 16 years, old older than Richard.  B.) When Hurley is 25, his age is 26 years old.  (1 + 14 + 25) - 24 = 16 years old

The given instruction is in bold font.<n><n>### Write a response that appropriates completes the statement.<n><n>### If your response contains a pun, use the sample above and put yourself in that position.<n><n>### You can use any of the following puns: “Let me handle this.” “Don’t sweat it.” “My turn to talk.” “Your choice.” These are just a few examples. Just be sure that the pun is appropriate.<n><n>### Here is a bonus: If you decide to use one of these phrases, be certain that it is appropriate and is a pun that pertains to the task at hand. Keep in mind that you can't be serious in one sentence and then use a pun the very next sentence. For instance, don’t say something like “I’ll handle this for you.” Then use pun next in the task.<n><n>### Also, make sure that there is no repetition in the message.<n><n>### Lastly, to make it more effective, make sure the pun fits in the context of the question. It doesn't sound right if you make the pun the wrong way. For instance, "Your choice" is not the same thing as "I'll handle this for you".<n><n>### To be clear, here are the steps: <n><n>### 1. Read the message.<n><n><n>### 2. Look at the task and read it carefully.<n><n><n>## Your response: You must write a response that appropriately continues the statement. Remember to include a pun that demonstrates the appropriate context of the task. Your response should be at least 14 characters in length.<n>

Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n>- The rowdy frat boys shout they will have fun and get laid tonight.<n>- These answers are incorrect.<n>- Only one answer is correct. The answer depends on if you were given "will" or "going to."<n>- These answers are the same.<n>- Choices E and D are both correct.<n><n>### Input<n><n>I have a 100-gallon drum that holds five liters. If I fill the drum 100% full and the drum empties completely on its own, what will happen to the amount of liquid it has at the end of the third day?<n><n>- On the first day the drum is just under 5 liters short of 100%<n>- On the second day it will only be a litre short of emptied<n>- On the third day it will be exactly 100% emptied<n>- There is no right answer<n><n>### Response<n><n>- On the 2nd day the drum would be 75% filled. It’s 75% of 5 is 3.75 liters and less than 100% of 5 liters.<n>- If the drum were to empty on the third day, the last day would be less than one full drum, the answer given is not possible.<n>- If emptied on the second day it would only be 100% on the last day.<n><n>### Response <n><n>- on the second day the drum would be slightly more than half full, it being 100 liters full minus 50 liters, the answer given is incorrect.<n>- on the third day 100 litres full minus 10, leaving the answer at 60, which is incorrect.<n><n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Answer the following choice questions correctly to determine the distance (in light-years) from Earth to the Sun.<n><n>Choice (A):<n>How is the distance from earth to the Sun calculated?<n><n>#### (C) One light year equals the speed of light. <n><n>### Response;<n><n>One light year is equal to 63,000 AU. The average distance measured between the planets in our solar system is 63,070,000 km per light year, which is 63,270,001 km.<n><n>### Choice (B)<n>What is the average distance measured between the Earth and the Sun?<n><n>### Response<n><n>One light year equals the speed at which light can travel in a vacuum through space. The Sun would cover 3,168,000 miles in one year.<n><n>### Answer (D):<n>How do we know that the distance from Earth to the Sun is 63,668,004.248 light years? <n><n>### Answer<n><n>This is the distance from Earth to a star located at least 2.5 light years away.<n><n><n>### Answer: (E)<n>How far away is the Sun if it travels (1 billion miles / 10 light years = 10,000,000 x 9 light years = 90 million) or 90,000 light years).<n><n>### Response <n><n>One light year = 186 million kilometers. Multiply (90,001,000) times (18,525,000,64,000 ) to get the result in light years.<n><n><n>## Task:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Task<n><n>If the answer is 9, the sum of 1, 3,

Put 56 characters in a blank box above the question! )Answer:<n><n>```java<n>public void main(){<n>	String n=input.nextLine();<n>	int g=input.nextInt();<n>	int y=input%g;<n>	if(n>0){<n>	while(y>0){<n>	switch(n){<n>	case int:<n>		System.out.println(y%int);<n>		y=y/int;<n>		System.exit(0);<n>	case decimal:<n>		System g.out..println(y/decimal);<n>		y%=decimal;<n>	case percentage:<n>		g.out.println(Dec.toint(y/(g*100)));<n>		y%=100*g;<n>	default:return;<n>	}<n>	}<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input::A group of 375 people decided to start an account and deposited $100 each into it. How much did that total deposit?<n>### Response: 37500<n><n>```java<n>import java.math.BigInteger;    <n><n>public class Deposite100{<n>BigInteger deposit=BigInteger.ZERO;<n>public static void main(String args[]){<n>try {<n>Class.forName("org.apache.commons.math3.special.GammaFunction");<n>GammaFunction.Gamma.getGamma( 10 );<n>Deposit.set( (args[0].split(" ")).length );<n>for(int i=1; i<args[0].split( " " ).length; i++){<n>Deposit=Deposit.add( BigInteger.valueOf((args[0].split()[0]).toDouble()).multiply(BigInteger.valueOf((args.split()[i]).toDouble())) );<n>}<n><n><n>    System.out.println("Total deposit: "+Deposit);<n>} catch (Exception e) {<n>    e.printStackTrace();<n>}<n>}<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>https://www.google.com/search?q=java

Meaning she finish work at evening. Which she will go home and prepare for her next days work by visiting her neighbor first.<n><n>### Question:<n>How many hours is the woman working per day?<n><n>### Solution:<n>The man works 12 hours per day.<n><n>### Problem<n><n>How is the man getting so tired?<n>### Solution: <n>A man usually works for 12 hours or more, and he sleeps less then 4 hours during these 12 hours. So after 12 hours of work, he will not get enough time to do some other activities.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Why is the woman working for 12 hours in a single day?<n><n>## #solution<n>The woman is working in 12 hours because the man takes around 12 hours of rest every day. Then the woman takes the work for another 12 because the man doesn't want to do and she has to provide for him.<n><n>### solution<n><n><n>How does the woman know that the man works for 12 whole hours at a single day?<n>### solution<n>A woman needs to clean the house and make it beautiful. Because to get more income from the market she has to clean her house very well, her neighbours can also be her customers. She will earn more money and she will start living a good life. After her work is finished she will go to the market to buy things. These will be the things for her home improvement. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		Answer: B - Intercourse<n><n><n>![instructions][9]<n><n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>We are going to use an algorithm called bubble sort. Bubble sort is one of the simple and oldest technique to sort the unsorted array into ordered array or vice versa<n><n>![instruactionsort][10]<n><n>##### Input:<n>Bubble Sort(Input (n)) is an algorithm that repeatedly compares adjacent elements in an array, swaps them if they are in the wrong order, and repeats this process until the array is sorted.<n><n>If we use bubblesort the worst case is the same as it’s the sorted case, because the algorithm always takes the longer path. <n><n>The bubblesort makes the same number of swap and moves as the original array is ordered, because it always takes the longer path since the algorithm does a comparison on each element. <n><n>The performance is O(n^2) because it does n swaps and takes n steps.<n><n>![bubblesort][11]<n><n>##### Demo:<n><n>We create a function that contains 3 variables<n><n>`var n=Array.length`;<n><n>`var a=Array;`<n><n>`var i=0;`<n><n>### Response Explanation: <n>You have to go through the original array starting with element 0 and element 1 and comparing the both to each other to determine if they are in the same position in the original Array and if they are in the position we want to swap them.<n><n>In this example for the input (9) we should go 0 through 8 to determine the place they have in our original input array. <n>The first thing we need to do is to define each element's position in the array and check if a[0]> a[1] then i = 1; if then we want to swap<n><n>```javascript<n>function sort(n){   <n>    var i,a,i;<n><n>    for ( i = 0; i <=n; i === i+1){<n><n>        for (i = 1; i <=n;i++ ){   <n><n>        if (a[i-1]> a[i]){<n><n>            Swap(n,i,i-1);<n><n>        }<n><n>        }<n>    }<n><n>

Whenever a woman wants to do her hair and makeup, she goes to either of the women and book an appointment.  Both women are equally trained and are able to handle all sorts of styles and make sure that their clients are happy.  However, because their schedules are so different and full, each woman has to make sure she is on time and is only able to book another client after one has successfully finished with their appointment.  In this case, the scheduler allows the owner to make the decision of which woman should be the next scheduled appointment.<n><n>### Feature:  Do you think this feature could also be used in another context? If the member of staff chooses to send the email twice, what day does the email get sent?<n>```<n>A: Saturday<n>```<n>### Instrction#3: You have a birthday party for your friends in three days.
